PETITION.TITLE: Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australians believe in freedom and democracy for all people.
2. The annexation of the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to USSR is not recognised as lawful by Australia; these Baltic states were illegally occupied by USSR.
3. Lithuanians have suffered their own `Katyn massacres' after the infamous Stalin-Hitler pact of 1939.
4. Lithuania's restoration of independence of 11 March 1990, is a peaceful and democratic expression of the desires of the overwhelming majority of the peoples of Lithuania.

5. Australian Government should support the democratically elected Government of the Republic of Lithuania, headed by President V. Landsbergis. Australia should extend humanitarian aid to Lithuanian peoples and full recognition of the Lithuanian Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate. The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would reduce biodiversity, compromise animal welfare, concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
(1) The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more.
(2) The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1 That the Goat Fibre Levy Collection Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 386 and made under the Goat Fibre Levy Collection Act 1989, be disallowed.
2 That the Juries (Amendment) Ordinance 1989 being Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 61 of 1989 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.
3 That the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 35 and made under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, be disallowed.
4 That the Overseas Defence Determination 1990/36 made under section 58b of the Defence Act 1903, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This notice is being moved because it is at the end of the time available for such action. The Committee's concerns relate to the provision for a strict liability offence, for a less than desirable form of search warrant, for a reversal of the usual onus of proof so that it now lies with the defendant, and with an instrument which includes more than 100 handwritten annotations without initials or other form of authentication. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the concerns of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES COMMITTEE
Goat Fibre Levy Collection Regulations
Statutory Rules 1989 No. 386

These Regulations provide that a search warrant ``may'' be in a form prescribed in a Schedule, rather than using a mandatory form. The Committee regards the authorisation of persons to enter private premises, in this case if necessary with assistance, by force and at any time of the day or night, as a serious matter which requires careful scrutiny. In this case the Committee was especially vigilant as the parent Act permits such warrants to be issued by a magistrate or justice of the peace. The Committee, together with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, usually prefers to see the safeguard of a warrant issued only by a judge or magistrate. The Committee appreciates, however, that in some remote areas where goat production occurs it may not be practicable for a judicial officer to issue warrants. This is all the more reason, therefore, for the additional safeguard of a mandatory form of an instrument which authorises what would otherwise be a serious breach of personal rights.
Juries (Amendment) Ordinance
A.C.T. Ordinance No. 61 of 1989

This instrument makes it an offence for an employer to penalise an employee who has been summoned for jury service. This provision, however, reverses the normal onus of proof which, of course, is on the prosecution. If the elements of the offence other than the reasons for the employer's action are proved, the onus of proving that a dismissal, injury or alteration of an employee's position to that employee's prejudice was not because the employee was summoned to serve as a juror is on the employer.

The Committee regards a reversal of the onus of proof as requiring detailed explanation. Such provisions have potential for serious breaches of personal liberties and are closely scrutinised by the Committee.
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment)
Statutory Rules 1990 No. 35

These Statutory Rules make it an offence for a person operating a vessel or hovercraft passing through specified areas of the Park to discharge more than 20 persons a day. The penalty was $5,000. There was no defence of reasonable excuse or any requirement of wilful intent in the provision, making it a strict liability offence. The Committee always questions strict liability offences and will accept them only in extraordinary circumstances and with great reluctance, as they are prima facie a breach of personal liberties.
In the present case, for example, it would appear there is no defence if the person operating the vessel or hovercraft discharges more than 20 people for reason of fire, shipwreck or other emergency.

Following previous correspondence with the Committee in connection with earlier amendments the Minister undertook to provide defences for other strict liability offences in the Regulations and the parent Act was amended to remove strict liability from certain offences provided in the Act.
Overseas Defence Determination 1990/36
Defence Act 1903
This Determination had more than 100 hand written alterations to the printed copy with no initials or other apparent explanations of their authenticity.

Most protective notices of motion given by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee relate to the protection of personal rights and the provision of appropriate review of administrative decisions affecting individuals. This is an example, however, of such notice being given in respect of a breach of parliamentary propriety. Delegated legislation confers rights and imposes duties in the same way as Acts of Parliament and the standards which apply to executive law-making should not be less than the standards of Acts. Just as it would not be acceptable for an Act to have any, to say nothing of 100, unexplained additions, delegated legislation should not be made, tabled or supplied to the public unless it complies with these standards.

That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency, namely, that to conform to the goal of a sustainable national economy the Government should seek to stabilise the size of the Australian population.

Mr President, that is a very important question; it is one about which I have views. I congratulate Senator Coulter for raising it. I think it is an important question to be raised publicly. The problem is that now Senator Coulter has presumably written a letter withdrawing his motion, the Senate will not have an opportunity to discuss it.

The population control lobby will continue by backdoor methods to attempt to influence policy decisions without the matter coming before this chamber. I say very clearly that the bottom line of moves by the population control lobby is the violation of fundamental human rights-that is, the right of parents responsibly to make decisions affecting their intimate relationships in terms of the number of children that they have. It is a fundamental question of human rights. Of course, except for Senator Coulter, the population controllers are not prepared to have the debate out in the open. They prefer to write speeches for Ministers and include in them such comments as:

But the thing that worries me more than a little bit about sustainable development is that no-one seems to be against it. I am yet to meet anyone who says they are against it. A bit like apple pie and, until we realised the implications of accelerated population growth, motherhood.
This comment appeared in a speech of Senator Richardson in Melbourne last December.

What did we see last week? We saw a report of a proposal before the Federal Government to cut out family allowances for 12- to 16-year-olds. That has now been denied by Senator Robert Ray but was not immediately denied by Senator Richardson. So this sort of population control push will be responsible for the development of an anti-family, anti-child mentality and could allow future governments to get away with anti-child policies.

Mr President, I have no intention at all of canvassing the motion put forward by Senator Coulter. However, I do congratulate his fellow Australian Democrats for influencing him in withdrawing that motion. I think that is very realistic on their part. They appreciate, as I do, that anyone who goes along the line is not only going down the track of violation of human rights and the development of an anti-child mentality in Australia, but also the promotion of a stagnant economy and national sterility. In conclusion, I hope--

As to the question of objecting to the showing of this particular film, the Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls,on Palm Sunday, that is very much a programming matter for the ABC. TALK.START.PARA: —It was not the program; it was the timing of it. There was a lack of sensitivity.

—With regard to the timing and the lack of sensitivity, I point out that the total number of complaints were something in the order of 100 plus nationwide. With the greatest respect to Senator Walters, I have to say that in terms of testing the faith of Christians being forced-indeed no-one was forced-to sit in the comfort of their living room wrapped around a cup of tea and a lamington watching the Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls, a program with which one may have disagreed, is a hell of a lot of an advance on being thrown to the lions, which is what happened 2,000 years ago. I have no doubt also in saying that probably if those particular conditions of testing the faith were around today I and a lot of other Christians would be running around at the point of a spear saying, `Jesus who?'. I have to say with the greatest of respect to Senator Walters that I treat her complaints seriously, as does the ABC. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins has not read the question I put. I read it out a minute ago. I thanked Senator Collins. TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, having seen the program, I thought it was a very minor test of faith indeed. It has left my faith unshaken. SPEECH.PARA: To oversight the structure and application of broadcasting regulation which is responsive to current social and economic needs . . .
The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal objective states:

To ensure, via appropriate public debate, that as many Australians as possible have equitable access to a national commercial and public broadcasting infrastructure that is competitive, commercially viable and sensitive to the social, cultural, educational and entertainment needs of the community.

Despite what the ABC may think its rights are, I believe that, through the objectives set down in the explanatory notes, it has to become sensitive to the social, cultural, educational and entertainment needs of the community and to be responsive to the current social needs of the community. I saw the program, and the subsequent program, and my request on behalf of my constituents was not that it not be shown, but that it be shown on any other day except Palm Sunday or, indeed, during that holy week. TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Knowles is probably right; he has been too busy elsewhere. David Hill knew on 10 April that I wanted that answer. He said he had better things to do than personally to ring around the 72 regional stations, and indeed, it would be a waste of taxpayers' money for him to do so. I would agree with him entirely. What a dreadful thing for the Managing Director to tell me that that is how the ABC is run. I would have thought that the ABC would have been run in a far more productive fashion, but if that is how our 9c each a day is expended, I would certainly suggest that things ought to be conducted in a different way.

SPEECH.PARA: I still believe it is quite legitimate for me to ask how many complaints throughout Australia the ABC had in regard to that program. The Managing Director should be able to give me that figure from the 72 regional stations. It is not a figure that is difficult to get. Surely to heavens people in the outback who make a complaint should be allowed to know that that complaint reaches the ABC and is not ignored. The implication by the Minister today is that it would be too expensive and too difficult to get the number of complaints. If it is a fact that complaints from people in the bush are ignored because they do not happen to live in a capital city, I would be most surprised. I want the answer to these questions: how many complaints throughout Australia did the ABC get? At what stage does the ABC start taking note of public opinion and respond sensitively to the social needs of Australians?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am still clinging grimly to the biblical stricture that a soft answer turneth away wrath. I do feel, with the greatest respect, that the Committee has canvassed this issue to a point where we really should be getting on with something else. I do take seriously Senator Walters's complaints. I think I indicated that by the degree to which I went to get answers.

SPEECH.PARA: I have answered Senator Walters's substantive question twice now but I will now answer it for the third time. There is no set number of complaints that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has laid down in its guidelines that would trigger a response from the ABC to cancel or alter a program. If, in accordance with Senator Walters's desires, the ABC did lay down a set number of complaints, I would have to say that personally I would start to wonder very seriously about the expertise of the management of the ABC. There is no magical number of complaints that triggers a situation where a program would actually be altered or deleted from the program. On every occasion the ABC would have to use its good judgment as to how it should respond.

In relation to the question of dealing with issues sensitively, I think that the ABC comprehensively does that. It also has an obligation not to deliver pap, and I hope that it continues to adopt a policy of delivering programs that provoke comment and debate in the community-provided they do not always end up in debate in the Senate in the final week.

But the question concerns the decision to broadcast this particular program on Palm Sunday. Senator Walters is entitled to her view on the matter. So are her constituents. She has clearly disagreed-and at length-with the ABC for its decision to broadcast the program on Palm Sunday, and I think she has had a very good opportunity to broadcast those concerns not just to the Committee but, since today the proceedings here are being broadcast, to the nation as well.

As far as the regional stations are concerned, I cannot be more forthright than I have been already. The ABC did not have the resources in all of its regional stations around Australia to record the complaints made about this particular program and it would be unreasonable, in my view, to impost that duty on it. I think that the detailed list of complaints, compliments and requests for re-broadcasting of the program from the cities that have been nominated give a reasonable indication to Senator Walters of the depth of the complaint. As a senator, to want to go any further than this one would have to ask what I think is a very reasonable question at this time, that is, what at the end of the day is the object of pursuing the matter to this point? What is the object of this particular exercise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is anxious on his own terms to bring this debate to a close, but I think it is a matter of sufficient importance to analyse the answer he has provided to the Committee on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I regard it as smacking of casuistry to say that the ABC takes every complaint seriously, the inference being that one complaint is taken as seriously as 10,000. I do not think that that ought to be the case and I do not think that Senator Collins, in his simplistic manner, can brush it off by saying, `Of course, there cannot be a quantitative level above which you take it seriously and below which you do not'. Of course, that is right but that is a straw man.

SPEECH.PARA: The real question is: What circumstances and what level of complaints prompt the ABC to take action which it would not otherwise take in response to complaints? I regard the note about the organised campaign of phone-ins as a clear indication that the ABC discounts complaints which it regards as organised. If that is the case--

TALK.START.PARA: —What a twisted interpretation. There is another equally viable explanation.
—Tell me. Just remind me.
—When you sit down, I will, Senator.

—If Senator Collins is going to trouble the Senate again, he might as well trouble us now, but I will give him the opportunity to deal with it later. It seems to me that that is an example of the ABC wanting to make its own in-house subjective judgments without telling the world what the objective criteria are. There have been a number of problems and complaints in the past about the ABC's method of processing complaints. The ABC is very determined to keep itself away from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). It says that somehow it ought to have an additional licence and ought to be able to run material that somehow might go a bit further than that on the commercials, presumably on the basis that the people who watch the ABC are of more rigorous disposition than, or are not quite as sensitive as, those who watch the commercials, who need more protection. But, when pursued in the Estimates Committee hearing, David Hill, as I recall it, said that about 99.9 per cent of the ABC's standards complied with those of the ABT. I cannot see how in the present situation anyone can really justify that sort of fine distinction. Nonetheless, the ABC is determined to maintain it.

SPEECH.PARA: Then it goes further and says that in a sense everything is serious and nothing is serious. I do not regard that as a satisfactory response. There ought to be guidelines and some way of informing the public at which point the ABC will take something seriously. We can say that is just a matter of judgment but that does not help me, because it is the length of the chancellor's foot. Whose judgment is it? Is it the local manager in Hobart? He says, `I got more complaints than anyone in the nation but they were organised so my advice to you is not to take that seriously'. If there were more complaints in Sydney people would say, `That is a bigger population so you can discount that'. If there were only 46 in Melbourne people would say, `That is an infinitesimal amount'. People can always disregard levels of complaints if they want to. Some 100,000 people might ring in but people can discount them all as organised or simply say, `This is just an issue of the moment and we do not regard it as an issue of national importance'.

In other words, if people want to they can take a very small level of complaint seriously; if they want to they can take a very large number dismissively. That is why I say it is not good enough to say, `We take everything seriously; it is then a matter of judgment'. No-one in the public then knows whether anything is going to be taken seriously to the point of it causing a different response. If people ring up and are told, `Thank you very much, we will record your complaint', where does it go? Why bother in the first place? I am going to be discouraged from ever complaining if my understanding is that the ABC might or might not, if it is so minded on the day, do something because somebody thinks it is worth while. That is not very satisfactory to me and, I suspect, the rest of the Australian community.

The Minister ought to be less protective of the ABC and more concerned to establish some sort of system of guidelines in which the public can have some degree of confidence that the ABC ought to be allowed to maintain its independence from the ABT and provide some sort of serious reaction to community complaints instead of in effect treating itself as above the public and adhering to a standard which it regards as somehow better than that of the rest of the community or, conversely, that the rest of the community really does not understand what the ABC is on about.

Unless the Minister does that we will continue to get the sorts of complaints that Senator Walters gets and the views that many people around the countryside will express at least privately, and not through the media, which is probably the only venue that the Minister would take seriously. They do that because they have an acute sense of frustration and simply do not know what it will take to provoke the ABC ever to do something that might in fact be a mainstream view but a view it will dismiss because, in its judgment, it did not result in a sufficient level of complaints. I do not think that is good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —All this exercise demonstrates is what an absolute travesty Estimates committee processes are as implemented by the Opposition in the Senate. The Estimate committees are running true to form, and one of these days, when the Opposition decides to use Estimates properly, perhaps this sort of nonsense will not be perpetuated. On the night these matters were being discussed I sat as the duty Minister in Estimates with a budget variation of $75m for Aussat Pty Ltd, just to pick one from memory. That is a fairly significant budget variation.
—I thought it was $100m.

—It was $75m, a fairly significant budget variation, I would have thought, and one which frankly I was looking forward to having a substantive debate on-and I expected one-from the Opposition members who were present that night. I was looking forward to it for two reasons-first, the matter directly related to the supplementary appropriations and was contained in the papers, and, secondly, it was very substantial.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened instead was that I did not get a single question from an Opposition member relating to the $75m budget variation that was contained in the supplementary appropriations-not a single question. Instead, I got a long debate on a legitimate matter related to the programming of the ABC which had nothing-and still has nothing-whatever to do with the supplementary appropriations that we are now debating. In fact, because the matter has been raised again I feel some obligation-not a personal obligation but a professional obligation to David Hill-to point out the facts.

The facts are that on 10 April Senator Walters apparently had-and I take her word for it-a telephone conversation with David Hill. The ABC subsequently advised-I found out that this information was correct-that it was not required by either the Committee or the Minister to appear before that particular Estimates Committee because it did not have any additional budget appropriations in the supplementary appropriations. Therefore the ABC did not appear. As I, as Minister, wanted to take Senator Walters's concerns seriously I must say, without naming anyone, that I know some former Ministers who certainly would not have been so cooperative, and perhaps it is a dreadful lesson to me--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you want-a medal?

—No, I do not, but I would like to spend the Senate's time productively debating at least something that is before us instead of something that should not be. Perhaps the Opposition could leave this matter to a substantive debate on the programming decisions of the ABC, which it is perfectly able to bring on. But it should not be considered in the supplementary appropriations.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Estimates Committee hearing I sat at the table and did not get a single question from one Opposition senator concerning the $75m budget variation in Aussat-not one question-but I dealt forever with a matter that was not even related to the appropriations. All I am saying is that Senate Estimates Committee hearings are running true to form.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to debate your own agenda, do you?

—Not at all, but I want to say this for one very important reason. Senator Alston got up at a late hour during the Estimates Committee hearing for no other reason than because he felt-I could see it written all over his face-the overwhelming need to do so. Once again, he slated the ABC and said that it dealt with public complaints with contempt. All of this is related to an alleged difficulty in getting answers from the ABC. But it was raised during consideration of the supplementary appropriations, of which the ABC did not have any. The fact is that the ABC, including its General Manager, has appeared regularly before Estimates committees and will do so again when it is required to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one very mild criticism of Senator Walters: perhaps it would have been more conducive to a proper debate-that is to actually have something before the Chair of this Committee that should be there-if Senator Walters had taken an opportunity that is entirely within her province, as I have certainly done it in the past, to have had a discussion with her Estimates Committee and through it, or through representatives from her side of the chamber on another Estimates committee, to have expressed her desire to have the senior executive of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, or, indeed, any other officer from any other government department, appear at an Estimates committee hearing at which he was, in fact, not required to do so because the ABC had no supplementary appropriations. Senator Walters did not do that and I have satisfied my inquiries that there was no formal request on the part of the Committee for the ABC to appear.

It is not reasonable-I get back to this dreadful business of being reasonable-for Senator Walters to assume that, because she as an individual senator had approached David Hill, and because David Hill knew about the matter as a result of her having talked to him on 10 April, he should have simply assumed that he was therefore required to appear at an Estimates committee meeting to consider supplementary estimates even though the ABC was not seeking any. That is not reasonable. What Senator Walters should have done-if I could be provoked into providing this mild criticism-if she considered this to be a matter of such great moment, was to have debated and raised the matter at a meeting of the appropriate Estimates committee and ensured that there was a committee request for David Hill to appear.

As the Minister at the Estimates Committee hearing responsible for this area, I said-this appears in the Hansard, and I recall saying it-that my attitude, generally, towards this kind of thing is that when a reasonable request is made directly to me to have an officer appear at an Estimates committee hearing I will try to accommodate that request if it is reasonable to do so. But I do not think it is reasonable, on this a broadcast day, for people who may be listening to the Senate proceedings today-the two or three men and their dogs who may be listening-to go away with the impression from this debate that the ABC was reluctant to appear, unhappy to appear or churlish in refusing to appear, which is the impression that has been created. The fact is that the ABC was not at the Estimates Committee hearing because it did not have any supplementary appropriations and it was not required to be there. There was no request either from me, as the Minister, or from the Committee that the ABC should be present because there was no reason why a request should have been made at the time. The ABC has always appeared, with its chief executive, at Estimates committees when it has been required by a committee to be at those Estimates committees, and it will continue to do that in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the Minister's comments, I do not blame the Minister for forgetting what occurred in the Estimates Committee hearing. He has a lot on his mind and I do not intend to get stuck into him in a similar vein as he has seen necessary to abuse me. I will read from the Hansard account of the Estimates Committee hearing and it might jog the Minister's memory. It states:

—I expected Mr Hill to be present today, because I had spoken to him on 10 April. I indicated then that I would see him at Estimates and would ask him questions, so he knew I wanted to ask him questions. He indicated to me at that time that he would be here, when he said, `Yes, Senator'. I do not understand why he is not here.

SPEECH.PARA: ACTING CHAIRMAN-Minister, --

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.

—Okay. The Minister has just said `I do'. If the Minister means by that smart alecky reply that it was because Mr Hill would then have had to answer questions, perhaps that is accurate, but I do not believe it is. I had indicated, as it states in the Hansard, that I had spoken to Mr Hill, to say that I would see him at Estimates and that I wanted to ask him certain questions which I gave him at that time. He indicated to me that he would be present. However, at the Estimates hearing I then said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I wanted to ask him questions at Estimates. He said, `Yes, Senator', and I took it from that that he had indicated he would be here. That is why I did not ask specifically for his attendance through the Secretary.

That is a quote from the Hansard. Certainly I will never trust this procedure again and I will ask for his presence through the Secretary. But I had understood-because Mr Hill had told me so himself; he had said `Yes, Senator'-that Mr Hill would see me at the Estimates committee hearing.

For that reason I believe the Minister, very graciously, allowed me to ask those questions. But do not let us get sidetracked into saying that I had no right to ask those questions. I had asked Mr Hill to be present at the Estimates Committee hearing. He had assured me that he would be there. The Minister indicated that he would accommodate my questions. He said:

These questions are not strictly relevant to the appropriations. I am anxious to accommodate Senator Walters. Let me accept her previous offer to accept them on notice. I will ensure that you are given answers.

I thought that that was generous of the Minister but he is not the only Minister that does that. It has been done on many occasions previously. The Minister has berated me and said that I should have gone about it in a different way. But this was already explained in the Hansard.

I have not had a chance to read it, but I did get a copy of ABC Editorial and Program Practices in Radio and Television. It says that the role of the ABC is to `contribute to the development of values within the community'. If the ABC sees the values of the community in one way, and members of the community, no matter where they are, do not believe it is abiding by those values, I believe that members of the community have a right to be able to ring in and voice their concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do. Even in organised campaigns they do it, and they do it all the time.
—Good. Senator McKiernan says they do. But the only figures that come to the managing director are from capital cities. Is that good? By interjection, please answer me.
—Do not call for interjections, Senator Walters.
—Senator McKiernan has been telling me--
—I am not going to breach the Standing Orders.

—Not when it does not suit the honourable senator. According to the Minister, if one lives in a capital city and rings in complaints, they will be recorded, and no doubt the managing director, if he so sees fit, will be informed of the number. But should one live in the bush, the ABC, with 72 regional stations, will never hear about it.
—That is nonsense.

—Senator Collins told me-and for heaven's sake, please correct it; I hope it is nonsense-that those 72 regional stations were too poor, that they had only two or three people to staff them sometimes, or something stood in the way. But I cannot get the numbers of complaints from those 72 regional stations because the managing director does not know about them.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe for a minute that Mr Hill is being so disruptive that if he knew how many complaints had come from the 72 regional stations, he would not be giving them to Senator Colston. He told me he was not going to waste taxpayer's money personally ringing around to find out. Senator Colston has told me that their staffing levels are too low to send in the complaints. No?-good. I am glad he is shaking his head. But that is actually what he said, according to my reading of Hansard. But I am anxious to get that figure of an Australia-wide protest. Senator Colston is telling me it is not available.

TALK.START.PARA: —That should be the end of it.
—That should be the end of it. So what the honourable senator is saying is that if the Managing Director is completely unaware of the complaints from the bush, that should be the end of it.
—You are misrepresenting me and you know it.

—Then the honourable senator said if they are not available, that should be the end of it. So if we do not know what the bush is saying, that should be an end of it. I am not prepared to accept that that should be an end of it. Since the Minister has told me that I have misunderstood his statement and that the bush really is looked after and we do know the numbers from the bush, then I ask him to give those numbers to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is little wonder that politicians are held in the low esteem that they are by people in this country listening to this nonsense. The patience of the Senate should be properly exhausted at this point in time. This question was widely canvassed. I must say this, and I hope it will not affect the way in which I conduct myself at Estimates committees in the future--
—It will affect me.

—Indeed, and I must say I will be properly brought into line by the Chairman of future committees if I am stupid enough to attempt to genuinely accommodate a question which was totally out of order at that particular Estimates committee. I can recall my very first experience at Senate Estimates committees. I was appalled by the rafts and rafts of highly paid and very competent public servants swanning around in corridors in the old Parliament House. I still remember my first experience with Estimates where a particular group of individuals-four of them-from a particular section of a particular department who were last cab off the rank to be called, and who had waited in the corridor since 2 o'clock that afternoon, came before the Estimates Committee. I can remember discussing this with some Opposition senators on the night. This group sat down at the table and were not asked a single question, having been kept there for six hours. I know that that does not happen any more-or very rarely-because strenuous efforts have been made by senators and by officers of the Senate to better regulate the procedure of Estimates committees to ensure that that does not happen. But I know that it is very much on the mind-and this has been an object lesson, I am sure, that will perhaps accelerate the debate-to try to make Estimates committees more regulated, more meaningful, and more important to the Opposition in terms of its use of them, by making sure that what is debated at Estimates committees is relevant to the appropriations that are being debated by those committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I could indulge in a bit of self-criticism and criticism of the Chairman of the Committee on the night, Senator Crowley. It was probably my fault and Senator Crowley's fault that we did not in fact insist that the Senate Committee only discuss those matters for which there were appropriations-which is what we should have done. I stand condemned for that. The reason that I tried to give Senator Walters an abbreviated answer was to try, in the fourth consecutive week of the sitting of the Senate, in dealing with this matter which should not even be in here in this form because it is not elated to appropriations, to shortcircuit the answer. I did this by tabling the ABC Editorial and Program Practices in Radio and Television, in which the answers to Senator Walters's questions are contained. I must say that for someone who is taking such a passionate interest in how complaints are handled by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), I would have thought that she would have had this document memorised like holy writ. I am surprised she has not.

I refer Senator Walters to page 30 of this document. Not only does it deal with program complaints but, also, on the same page it deals with that vexed subject of religious programming. I must say it is very interesting that the ABC is being vilified for what one particular group of people takes great offence at in terms of the timing of the program, not its content. Senator Walters has been insistent that she was not saying that the program should not have been put to air; she is not into censorship in that sense. The complaint just concerned the insensitive timing. But I have not heard any commendation from Senator Walters for the excellent Christian programs that have been broadcast on the ABC, such as the Doogue programs, a number of which I have watched and thought were excellent. The ABC in fact has a very comprehensive programming schedule in religious programs, which is laid out at paragraph 7.12 on page 30, where it says:

The ABC broadcasts a wider and more comprehensive range of programs dealing with religion than commercial broadcasters; its religious programs cover worship and devotion, explanation, analysis, debate and reports.
I am sure that has got something to do with the difficulty of getting sponsors for such programs. It continues:
Religion include Christianity, other traditional religions and new religious movements, as well as analysis and discussion of religious issues from non-religious points of view.
I would hope that the ABC continues to implement such a policy and is never deterred in putting to air programs that may attract a little bit of controversy. It goes on to say:
The ABC aims to explore developments in religion; it does not promote any particular theology or form of religious expression.
And in my view, neither should it. It continues:

In responding to the needs of Australian audiences, it is inevitable that Christianity attracts a major proportion of the ABC's attention; however, the ABC does not see its role to be that of necessarily reinforcing Christian values. Rather, the ABC attempts to reflect the liveliness of debate and concern which religious issues encourage.
I find it very difficult to imagine that any reasonable person could disagree with that as a programming ethic for the ABC's religious programs.

It then goes on-and I conclude on this point-to detail what happens when people complain about programs of the ABC. That is laid out exhaustively on pages 30 and 31 of this document. I refer Senator Walters and any other honourable senators to it rather than reading it all out into Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to take exception to Senator Collins's characterisation of my remarks as saying that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) treated complainants with contempt. I thought I was at pains to demonstrate that it ought to have mechanisms in place that allow the public to have some confidence--
—It has.
—Just a minute, smart alec, if you would not mind.
—Order! That is not a proper remark. It should be withdrawn.

—I withdraw it, but I take just as much exception to having words put in my mouth as Senator Collins clearly does to being labelled in that manner. I would have thought that there is a very real difference. I simply want to say that I have long held the view that the ABC does itself a great--
—There is a life after the Senate.

—If the Minister listened, he might learn something. The ABC would do itself a great service if it were to take complaints seriously to the point where it was prepared to collate them, and not simply-as it did in this instance, after Senator Walters had pursued the matter-come up with some statistics six weeks later. It should have in place a mechanism that allows those facts to be brought to the attention of the managing director or someone in a high position of authority straight after the event so that sensible judgments can be made about, in particular, what constitutes a sufficient level of complaints to take the matter further. That could be done in terms of quantitative levels or otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply make the point that the ABC does not help its own case by effectively taking the view that it will decide in its own time, in its own place, whether it ought to be taking any further action. That is tantamount to saying that whether it gets one complaint or 10,000 complaints, it will make the decision. If that is the view it takes, it might as well not even know how many complaints it has. I suspect in many instances it does not and did not know on this occasion until some weeks later. I do not argue that the ABC is treating people with contempt. I simply say that it is doing itself a disservice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The ABC does, in fact, have such mechanisms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not entered a great deal into consideration of the Additional Estimates. I will be doing so with a great deal more vigour when the general Estimates are considered in September. I must say, Mr Chairman, I would hate it to go by the board if the chamber were to accept that some type of regimentation was to be imposed on honourable senators in respect of Estimates.
—Supplementary Estimates.

—In response to Senator Colston, I must say that he has been an admirable chairman, certainly at the times that I have been present. I feel that in many ways I am able to get responses by placing them on notice and asking the departments to come up with the answers beforehand so that the Committee has something before it, just as well as by other means. But the Committee must realise that honourable senators do have the right to question the officers at a time when it actually suits them, because, after all, they have the obligation to represent their constituents. I would hate anything said here-I hope the Minister is not suggesting this-to be seen as an attempt to limit in any way the responsibilities and rights of honourable senators to represent their constituents in this most important function of audit and control of government expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not entering the broad debate in respect of whether the program in question was appropriate or whether the timing was appropriate. I will enter it anywhere else, but not here, because I just happen to have the view that a lot has been said here. Certainly at some stage I would like to take up what Senator Collins was talking about in respect of the material that is before him and available to us, that is, the statement by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) that it does not see its role as reinforcing Christian values. I wonder whether it sees its role as undermining Christian values. Frankly, that is a very interesting question that might be asked of Mr Hill at some stage.

I say to the Committee and to Senator Collins, through you, Mr Chairman, that long before he came in here, the question of the adequacy of complaints to the ABC from viewers and listeners was canvassed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read the debate.

—I wonder whether Senator Collins has read the correspondence received by me and the undertakings given to me on a particular occasion by the then Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, about the complaints procedures of the ABC because definite undertakings were given. I have the feeling now, very clearly, that the general public believes that the complaints procedures adopted by the ABC lack credibility. Any complaint procedure where there is appeal from Caesar to Caesar must lack credibility. That is the situation so far as the complaints procedures are concerned in the ABC. That has a long history and I am just waiting for the appropriate time to raise again the undertakings that were given to me on that previous occasion about the need to look at an independent assessment of complaints about ABC programs, either on radio or television, by a body independent of the ABC so that complainants do not have to appeal from Caesar to Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise one point only-that is to remind honourable senators of the legislation we passed in this place with regard to the new organisation of how complaints are handled. I am surprised at some of the comments of Senator Harradine, simply because the method by which complaints are handled in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is not a matter for the ABC, but for legislation. Indeed we had a very long debate in this place about how they would be handled. It is not an appeal from Caesar to Caesar. A separate community organisation has been established. It seeks, over time, new people to come on board. It is a shadowing organisation that was a matter of a very long debate in this place and a matter of amendment in this chamber as to how it would be set up to operate. It was strengthened when the legislation came here.

SPEECH.PARA: I find this debate somewhat strange because the organisation which we put in place is a very good one. I think it has operated very well. I have had a great deal of interest in following through the various things that the community shadowing organisation has been doing and finding out who is on it in every State.

It is involved not only with complaints. It is a proactive organisation, not just simply a reactive organisation, and it is a body to which the ABC is required by legislation to give information. It is also a body which, by legislation, is required to advise the ABC on community attitudes. I have always thought that that is a far better way to go, so that the ABC can be monitored by that community organisation. If it is not working, then certainly the chamber ought to look at it. I take the view of Senator Walters and Senator Harradine, that it is not working. In that case, we ought to go back and look at the legislation. It is not simply a matter of the ABC; it is a matter of legislation passed and set in place by this chamber in which the community is given a role that it is not given with regard to any other licensee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

On this occasion, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, was of the same wont.

SPEECH.PARA: We had the question and there was some concern that the answer might not be here in time. An answer was given but it was not satisfactory to Senator Walters. We passed the Supply Bills last Friday afternoon but the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, gave an undertaking that, if necessary, there would be a debate on the matter this morning. Further answers have been provided. Again, Senator Walters is not satisfied with the answers. I can understand what she is saying and why she is dissatisfied.

My earlier point was that, as Senator Collins said, when these other answers that Senator Walters was seeking were not available, it should have been the end of the matter. By that I meant that if the answers are not available, any further questions by Senator Walters will not make them available. Senator Walters can express her displeasure at the fact that they are not available-I think she has done so and she can do so again if she so wishes-but if we are to go any further than that, we will have to go beyond this Committee debate and do what Senator Macklin suggested-look at the particular legislation which the Corporation is bound to follow. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories whether the Government will require certain sporting organisations to clean up their act, as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts in its report on drugs in sport. Will he consider linking contained Government funding to such organisations to compliance with the recommendations of that report?

Thus far that would appear to be working. We have had a number of examples of sports having made decisions at a national level to comply with our requirements.
