—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the official unemployment rates published by the Government. Has the Minister noted any relative improvement in the labour market position in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an issue with which I have kept in close touch because I often make visits to South Australia. I had a discussion with the Premier only two or three nights ago about a number of issues affecting the South Australian economy. In answer to Senator Maguire's question, South Australia has had a significant reduction in unemployment, taking it from having the fifth lowest rate in 1989 to the third lowest in March and April this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The absolute number of persons unemployed in South Australia, seasonally adjusted, has fallen from 52,000 in April 1989 to 48,000 last month. South Australia's share of total national unemployment has fallen from 10.4 per cent in April 1989 to 9.3 per cent in April this year.

Some of the important reasons for this are lead projects, such as the Australian Submarine Corporation and the Anzac ships, as well as other traditional manufacturing enterprises, such as the General Motors-Holden's plants in South Australia, which continue to contribute substantially to the health of the State's economy and provide a substantial boost to investment activity and future manufacturing capability for the State well into the next century. I should also point out that, in addition, housing starts have risen 3 per cent in South Australia in the last year, having been somewhat out of phase with national trends a year or two ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he is aware that, because of uncertainty in the future of the wool floor price-caused directly by speculation by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy-the Australian Wool Corporation has been forced to buy at least $300m worth of wool at recent sales more than it otherwise would have had to buy? Given that this increased buying was necessitated directly because of irresponsible speculation by the Minister for Primary Industries, will the Government immediately compensate the Corporation and, therefore, Australian woolgrowers, to the tune of at least $300m? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the last part of the question, `If not, why not?', the answer is no. And `Why not?'-because the suggestion comes from Senator Boswell. No intelligent commentators on the scene have really made that suggestion. Senator Boswell represents, if I might say so, something beyond the fringe in making the suggestion. Senator Boswell will be aware that the Australian Wool Corporation has been buying most of the Australian supply of wool for something in the order of 12 months, if not more. To suggest that as a result of recent wool sales the Wool Corporation is behaving in any different a manner from the manner in which it has behaved over the last 12 months is bordering on the ludicrous.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know why Senator Boswell addressed this question to me in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer, unless it is because of the nationwide concern about the minimal level of wool exports at the present time, which is of concern to all Ministers in the Government and particularly the Treasurer because of its impact on the current account. I do not know of any other reason why he would address the question to me except that I am in a position to deny what he describes as irresponsible speculation by the Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Kerin.

Mr Kerin has been very diligent in the last week in making his views known to both the Board of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia. He has made his views known not only to them but also to a wide variety of individual woolgrowers. To give the Minister's views as expressed to those bodies that title of `irresponsible speculation' is, I think, irresponsible in itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is Senator Button aware that before Easter, and before the speculation was started by Mr Kerin, the Australian Wool Corporation was buying 30 per cent of the wool and 70 per cent was being sold on the open market, and that, since the speculation, the situation has reversed-the Wool Corporation has had to buy 70 per cent of the wool and the market is buying only 20 per cent? That is why I asked the question. I do not believe the Minister has given me a correct answer.

—As I said in answer to Senator Boswell's original question, this is a difficult and long-term problem, and it is ridiculous to draw any conclusions of the kind he attempts to draw from the attitude stated by the Minister.
—Everyone accepts the problem faced by the buyers.

—Senator Hill is interjecting. When those on the other side of this Parliament actually work out what they want to do about this issue, things will be better. When Senator Hill makes noisy interjections similar to the views expressed in the question it shows obvious, distinct confusion in the Opposition ranks, which does not surprise me. Such confusion always occurs when the National Party of Australia perceives itself as having a vested winner interest which it wants to pursue-and it always gets it wrong. There is always this confusion between the Liberals and the Nationals at such times.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade received any confirmation of early press reports which indicate a heavy turn-out of voters and a significant vote for the National League for Democracy (NLD) in the elections in Myanmar? Does the Minister have any indication that the conduct of the balloting was other than free and fair? Will the Government urge the State Law and Order Restoration Council to hand over power if reports that the NLD has won the election are confirmed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The early reports we have received from our embassy-backed up by many of the widespread media reports-indicate that there was a very significant vote for the National League for Democracy. It also appears that the voter turnout was high, particularly in urban areas, but at this stage the situation in rural seats is such that virtually no results are available. I must also stress that the initial reports are very early, and are waiting further analysis by our embassy.

ANSWER.PARA: If it becomes apparent that the NLD has won a majority of seats in the new constituent assembly, the Australian Government will certainly continue to urge the military regime, in line with its own promise that the election would be free and fair, to effect a transfer of power in accordance with the expressed wishes of the people of Myanmar for democratic rule.

The military regime's promise that the election would be free and fair has been seriously undermined by its suppression of political dissent and intimidation of political opponents to limit their participation in the election. It is particularly regrettable that the leader of the main opposition party-the National League for Democracy-is still under house arrest and was disqualified from standing in the election. The Australian Government will be paying close attention to the result of the election in Myanmar and expects the military regime to abide by its undertaking that military rule is an interim measure, pending a transfer of power to the democratic government to be formed as a result of the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware that the figures released by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development earlier this year show that Australia's total expenditure on education, as a proportion of gross domestic product, has fallen to a level whereby we now rank tenth out of the 13 OECD countries? Does the Minister accept that these figures are accurate and, as stated in the OECD report, that Australia's funding for education is decreasing more rapidly than most other OECD countries? In view of the Government's stated policy of making Australia the clever country, will the Government increase education funding to a level commensurate with this goal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three parts to Senator Macklin's question. In respect of the first part as to whether I am aware of OECD figures, I say that I am.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in response to the second part of his question it should be acknowledged and recognised, as it is in the community, that international comparisons of education systems and expenditures are a public issue and will be for some time. Included in the debate are various claims and counterclaims about Australia's comparative position. The Government has cautioned-I think others have accepted the caution-about the validity of such comparisons for a range of reasons. There are, of course, particular problems relating to interpreting a particular country's statistics. In order to do so properly, one has to look at the particular education systems, the legislation involved and, of course, the social context in which the systems operate.

Those sorts of localised problems have immediate impact when applied to the definitions used by international bodies such as the OECD or the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO). For instance, Australia, in trying to respond to the UNESCO and OECD questionnaires, sometimes has been forced to fit within the definitions which those organisations apply. We presume that other countries have similar sorts of problems. But we are forced to fit within those definitions because of the peculiarities of our educational, legislative and social context.

The other point to make about the OECD comparison is that the figures leave very little room for qualitative assessments, especially regarding the efficiency and output of the education systems. It may well be-and Senator Macklin might acknowledge this-that the Australian education system is relatively efficient in comparison with some systems overseas. We may be getting better value for our money, but one really cannot make a clear assessment of that on the basis of the raw figures produced by the OECD.

However, it should be acknowledged that these figures also show the comparison between money spent on education by both public and private institutions. When we break down the figures and focus on the figures relating, for instance, to public expenditure, we find that in Australia the bulk of education expenditure is in the public sector. Internationally, Australia compares quite well. Publicly we spend at levels which approach that of France and which are greater than that of Japan and the United States of America, which puts us in the high range in terms of public expenditure on education internationally.

As I said at the start, this issue has been the concern of public debate for some time. As a response to that and to see what further comparisons can be made on this level, the Department of Education, Employment and Training has commissioned a series of case studies to look at individual countries and to see whether appropriate comparisons can be made. Already there have been studies on the Unites States of America, Canada and Japan but, in the assessment of those studies, one has to take into account the different contextual situations which we find. Speaking indirectly on the point of Senator Macklin's third question, which relates to the Government's stated policy of making Australia the clever country, I think our record of public expenditure stands very well internationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take the Minister's point about the difficulty of international comparisons. The point I raised is that Australia's expenditure on education is decreasing more rapidly than that of other countries. If the Minister wishes to talk only about government expenditure, the OECD 1986-87 figures put us at 5.3 per cent. The latest available figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics put us at 4.9 per cent. In other words, we are still decreasing our level of education expenditure each year. Is the Government in this area not responsible for the decreasing level of expenditure on education? This does not stand with its stated policy at the last election of developing a `clever country'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —To give a comprehensive answer to that point, I made the point earlier about the difficulty in making international comparisons. Senator Macklin then rightly went to comparisons within Australia. It is probably important to note three specific commitments of this Government over a short period in terms of education, particularly higher education, expenditure. For instance, by 1992 the Government will be spending something like $3.6 billion in the higher education area alone, which is $1.6 billion more than was spent in 1988. That in itself is a massive increase.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of higher education research, which cannot be divorced from education and from the ultimate target of making Australia a clever country, an extra $144m will be provided by 1992, with $1 billion to be allocated through the Australian Research Council over the next five years. That is a very strong commitment. Of course, $100m funding per year of cooperative research centres within the next five years is also a very strong commitment towards providing more funds and resources for the ultimate goal of raising education levels in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of a study recently considered by the British Cabinet which indicates that the extent and effect of global warming could be much greater than previously anticipated? Would the Minister inform the Senate what the latest information available to our Government on global warming indicates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain what the British Government has looked at in recent times, but it is clear that it is probably the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) working group report that was released in the last couple of weeks. The IPCC process has been going on now for a couple of years and is quite crucial to what happens with the reaction of the whole world, not just Australia, on this question of global warming.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole report from the International Panel on Climate Change will be available in July, so it can be discussed at length at the second world climate conference in November. The working group 1, which is assessing the science of the greenhouse effect and trying to advise on its likelihood and strength, met during May in the United Kingdom. It comprises some of the most eminent scientists around the world. Australia was represented by some people from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Bureau of Meteorology, and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. We have been a particularly good contributor to this, especially since the Government's initiatives last year announced by the Prime Minister for increased funding for our greenhouse studies.

I will just go through a couple of the main points of the executive summary of that working group. First off, the IPCC has concluded that the greenhouse effect is real, contrary to the notions of Senator Stone and some others in this place over time. It believes that man-made emissions will certainly lead to a warming of the earth's surface. The rate of expected increase of global mean temperature during the next century will be about 0.3 degrees celsius per decade. That will be greater than has been seen over the previous 10,000 years. By the year 2025, global mean temperatures will have risen about one degree above the present value, and three degrees before the end of the next century, although regional changes will not mean that every area will be exactly the same.

The sea level is expected to rise about 20 centimetres by the year 2030 and 65 centimetres by the end of the next century due to the expansion of the oceans and some melting of ice. Those predictions are not in line with some of the doomsday predictions of recent times; nonetheless, they would be very serious indeed for a whole range of communities around the world and would have serious implications for Australia as well.

In regard to global warming over the last 100 years, the science is inconclusive, as far as the IPCC is concerned, to estimate how much of that has been due to man-made greenhouse gases. It is concluded that rapid changes in climate will change the composition of ecosystems; some will benefit, and some will not. I only hope that Australia can fare well in those regional changes.

The IPCC estimates that stabilising the atmospheric concentration of the really long-lived greenhouse gases, such as chlorofluorocarbons, carbon dioxide, or nitrous oxide, at present levels would require reductions in man-made emissions of 60 per cent. For methane it would be a 15 to 20 per cent reduction.

These are enormous figures. They give us some idea of just how big a problem the world has to wrestle with over the course of the next few years. Australia will continue its efforts at the IPCC and will be studying this report in some detail and, come the second world climate conference in November, I hope that Australia can put up the strongest position possible and urge upon the world a responsible attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. What action has the Hawke Government taken in conjunction with the Malaysian and Indonesian authorities to prepare for the anticipated increase of Indo-Chinese boat people seeking refugee status in coming months? Is it a fact that Indonesia's main refugee camp on Galang Island is already overcrowded with more than 11,000 people? Is the Minister aware of the recent statement by the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Mr Ali Alatas, that `Indonesia would not push boats back out to sea, but it would help people who wanted to continue their journey to do so'? What are the consequences for Australia and our already stretched immigration, Coastwatch, customs, primary industry and defence authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling may be referring to a number of incidents and reports. I think most recent reports indicate that there may be more people coming to Australia primarily through Cambodia, which is the location that Senator Tambling refers to. Those reports have been around for some little while. It is also fair, in the total context, to acknowledge that at least three boats from Cambodia have recently arrived in various locations in Indonesia. The Government's information is that there have been encouraging reports that people on these three particular boats may be transferred to the holding centre on Galang Island. The Australian Government would hope that, in the interests of life and safety, the Indonesian Government would hold these, and any such other arrivals, in its territory. As recently as 3 May, the Indonesian Foreign Minister announced that Indonesia would continue to accept Vietnamese asylum claimants. The Minister indicates that a distinction is not being made between the treatment of Vietnamese and Cambodians.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is well aware of the serious pressure on Indonesia from growing numbers of Indo-Chinese asylum claimants. The population has already soared to 11,000, including several hundred Cambodians. In recognition of these particular pressures, the Australian Government provided $1.5m to Indonesia in late March to upgrade its camp facilities on Galang. Since then, there have been a number of senior official exchanges between Australia and Indonesia about the transit of Cambodian boats. These discussions are, in fact, going on.

It may be that the Cambodians themselves are expressing a determination to reach Australia. If this, then, is the case, it raises certain questions about their profile. To the extent that the Cambodians represent themselves as asylum seekers, the basis of their claim being a fear of their situation in their home country-asylum is essentially about flight to find a safe haven, not about shopping around for a preferred country in which to resettle-what they have done, in terms of getting to Australia, will obviously have to be taken into account.
To sum up, essentially Australia is well aware of the pressure on Indonesia and the pressure in this area. As I have said, discussions are ongoing with Indonesia in order to accommodate the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister acknowledged that there had been discussions and exchanges. The Minister mentioned the date of 3 May. Given that it is now almost a month since that date and in view of Mr Alatas's recent quoted statement that people would be encouraged to continue their journeys, I ask: Has there been any recent expression? What is the Government's reaction to the Indonesian Foreign Minister's recent statement? What planning is the Australian Government doing in regard to the immigration, Coastwatch, Customs, primary industries and defence authorities in order to meet any increase in activity adjacent to northern waters?
—Get your brief up to date, Nick.

—In response to Senator Hill, the brief is more up to date than 3 May. I indicated in my answer that the discussions between senior officials of Australia and Indonesia are ongoing. Senator Tambling has asked for more specific information. I will try to get that for him by tomorrow.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Will the Minister conduct an examination of the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric project of the Queensland Electricity Commission in view of its location in the centre of the wet tropics World Heritage area? If not, why not? Is the Minister satisfied to accept the findings of the Queensland Government's task force on this project when they are handed down? If so, what authority has been given to the task force to examine World Heritage values? Is the Minister aware that there are some 22 proposed developments within the wet tropics World Heritage area? What steps has the Minister taken to put in place the proposed management authority and when will it be in operation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tully-Millstream project certainly does impact on World Heritage values. The question then is: how great is the impact, and is that impact justified in view of the World Heritage Convention's own reference to acts of economic necessity? I think we all believe that the provision of electricity is an act of economic necessity. I did have a look at plans for the Tully-Millstream proposal in the middle of last year, and certainly the Queensland Electricity Commission has made a real effort to have the two endangered species concerned protected if the plan goes ahead.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, there needs to be a proper assessment of the kind of effect it can have on values. To that end, prior to the election I had been speaking with the Premier of Queensland about the Queensland inquiry and its term of reference. If my memory serves me correctly, the Premier had agreed that an assessment would be done on the power needs of Queensland to see whether this dam was an necessity as well as assessing the kind of environmental damage it would have. The Commonwealth awaits the report from Queensland on those matters, and we will assess it when it gets here.

It must be remembered that in the World Heritage area nothing can take the place of this dimension without Commonwealth approval, and obviously the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, will be having a very great close look at that report from the Queensland Government when it comes in.

There are a number of projects on the drawing board within the World Heritage area. Whether it is 22 or not I am not sure, but I will find out. With regard to what we are doing about the management of the area, there was an agreement on funds and staffing which the Prime Minister announced during the campaign. That was the culmination of some negotiations that I had been having over the previous three months. As to what has happened since then between Mrs Kelly and the Queensland Government as regards the timing of the introduction of a new authority, I am not certain, but I will endeavour to let Senator Dunn know tomorrow. However, my feeling is that the authority will be up and running in a very short space of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories aware that the Rhue collection, at present in Lawrence in the United States of America, is considered to be the largest private collection of Aboriginal artefacts outside Australia? Is he aware that unless a Federal Government funding commitment is given to assist South Australia in its bid to return it to its rightful place, the valuable collection could be lost to Australia forever? Therefore, following an approach to the Prime Minister earlier this month, can the Minister inform the House what commitment the Federal Government is prepared to make to ensure the return from America of the internationally renowned Rhue collection, following renewed interest in the collection from both American and Japanese interests?

—I have heard of the collection. I am not aware, however, of the current state of play. I will endeavour to find out from the present Minister, Mr Simmons, and see if I can inform Senator Olsen tomorrow.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL COMMISSION: NOTIONAL DISTRIBUTION OF PREFERENCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware that in Saturday's by-elections in Western Australia the State Electoral Commission facilitated a very early indicative result by carrying out a notional distribution of preferences from minor parties and independents? Will the Minister ensure that this sensible means of arriving at a speedy indicative result is employed by the Commonwealth Electoral Commission in all future Federal elections?
—And what was the result again?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that I have just recently become aware, only a few minutes ago, of the use by the Western Australian Electoral Commission of the system of notional distribution of preferences for minor parties and independents for the election on the weekend-which, as has been made perfectly clear by Senator Crichton-Browne, we won. In the form that the distribution was used it gave a very clear and early outcome indication and also gave an indication of the swing quite early. I am not sure whether this was able to be used in Western Australia because of the actual application of its Electoral Act or because of administrative procedures, but it is obviously going to be an important consideration in terms of assessing the Western Australian exercise. It is an exercise which does appear to have been successful, to the extent that it gave a very clear and early indication of the result.

ANSWER.PARA: The objective in any electoral process is to ensure the good conduct of the ballot and to do so as efficiently as possible. I suppose the ultimate aim is to meet the interests and needs of the electorate. In that context I will draw to the attention of the Australian Electoral Commission the experience of the Western Australian Electoral Commission and its use of notional distribution and ask it to have a look at the way it is operating in Western Australia, and also to advise me whether such distribution is possible within the Electoral Act in Western Australia or within the Australian Electoral Act, or whether it may need legislative change to be adopted federally.

I should also say that before the Government will make any real assessment on this particular issue the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters will, I anticipate, be looking at the election and all the problems in the way it was run-and, at the same time, at the efficiencies in the way it was run. I am sure that, given the degree of correspondence I have had on this particular issue and verbal representations, this will be one of the matters considered by the Joint Standing Committee.
In summation, it seems to have been a very useful and efficient exercise. We need to have a look at it through the appropriate mechanisms federally to see whether it can apply on a national level.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the value of the spares holdings for the Chinook helicopters exceeds $100m-and in fact, rumour has it, it is between $120m and $150m?

—I think that is a fact. Since the initial decision to mothball the Chinooks a full look at the inventories discovered there were more spares there and they were of a higher value than had initially been contemplated. That opens up a lot more options to the Government as to the future of those helicopters than we have had before. I expect, in the broader aspect of the question, to be announcing something in that regard in the next few months.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is it a reasonable assumption that if those spares were sold their recovery value would be of the order of 5 per cent of what we paid for them?

—They have not been put out for sale, and in case they are to be put out for sale I do not want to indicate a price at this stage. Obviously, anyone tendering would go well below what I am suggesting. I do not think that is the case but I will have a check in more general terms so that we are not in any way in danger of maximising our price if we decide to sell them. I will let Senator MacGibbon know the details of that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Have the Federal and State governments reached a significant agreement over dual appointments of the heads and other presidential members of State industrial tribunals to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the expected advantages of this new system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the Conference of Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers in New Zealand on Friday the State Ministers for labour and I reached agreement on a communique in which we agreed, in the case of the Commonwealth, to appoint the heads or presidential members of State tribunals to the Commonwealth Bench at deputy president level and, in the case of the States, which do not have a provision within their Acts, to amend their Acts to provide that deputy presidents or commissioners of the Federal Commission can be appointed in their States where appropriate. This will give rise to a blending of the State and Commonwealth tribunals, a greater degree of flexibility between both and a cutting down of the shopping between Federal or State jurisdictions from the point of view of trying to develop leapfrogging patterns on awards. It will also provide a greater commonality of standards as a consequence of the blending of the two commissions and it will break down the level of demarcation disputes and assist in a speedier and more flexible solution to industrial disputes in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: It is, I think, a significant reform. It is a reform that has been talked about for many years but has not been able to be achieved until now. ANSWER.PARA: It is always a trap in these questions, if I might say so, to relate one month's figures to another and not look at the broader picture. For example, if one looks at the imports in this recent current account figure for the month of April, one sees that there was at least one large aircraft in the import figures and in the declining imports of something of the order of 13 per cent-as I recall it; I do not have the figures in front of me-that is important because that is a very big item on any Australian monthly import Bill.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May Senator Coulter asked a question about the Ozone Protection Act. I indicated at the time that I would be able to respond about the Act after checking with the Minister. The Act does two things: it enables the Government to adhere to the Montreal Protocol and it provides for bans on the manufacture and import of a number of products which use chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). Schedule 4 of the Act invokes these bans, which go well beyond the Protocol. The ban on aerosols, for example, immediately reduced the use of CFCs in this country by 30 per cent. We can be proud of this achievement not only because we are one of the few countries that have done this, but also because it was done with the agreement of Australian industry. I am sure that Senator Coulter would be interested to hear that the corporations power of the Constitution have enabled these bans to be put into place.

ANSWER.PARA: The other arm of the Government's efforts to save the ozone layer is the national ozone protection strategy, developed with the States and Territories. The Act and the strategy together will see a 95 per cent reduction in the use of CFCs by 1995. Whilst the State governments have an important role in implementing the strategy, the Commonwealth is preparing regulations which implement various recommendations in this unique document. The drafting of these regulations is at an advanced stage and I expect them to be tabled during the next session. For Senator Coulter's interest, I have been informed that an Australian delegate at the recent meeting reviewing the Montreal Protocol commented that many countries are using the Australian strategy as a bible. Australia is the only English speaking country with such an advanced CFC phase-out strategy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May Senator Dunn asked a question on compulsory pilotage of vessels in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. There are international agreements to ensure the right of innocent passage by ships through international waters and territorial seas. As a consequence, any move to introduce compulsory pilotage requires international agreements and cooperation.

ANSWER.PARA: At the instigation of the Australian government, the International Maritime Organisation recommends that all ships greater than 100 metres or which carry hazardous substances, including oil, should carry a pilot while in waters off the Great Barrier Reef. About 90 per cent of ships carry a pilot and nearly all tankers are piloted. The Government does not believe that 90 per cent is good enough. The risks to the Great Barrier Reef are too high.

I am advised that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has urged those countries whose ships do not carry pilots to do the right thing. Also, it is investigating as a high priority other possible legal options, in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Transport and Communications and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

These options include imposing conditions on ships seeking access to Australian ports and the compulsory requirement to carry a pilot. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories regards this as a very important matter and is keen to pursue any additional legal options that are identified with our colleagues the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Attorney-General, and the Minister for Transport and Communications.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report to the Prime Minister by the Australian Science and Technology Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am very pleased that this report Small Country: Big Science has come down. I am impressed with its great title and the great thought behind it, but I am afraid that it will not make much of a splash. After years of decline, this recommendation will not turn the corner. Science in Australia is still in a terrible mess and a terrible depression by comparison with the other countries with whom we do business. The proposition as put forward in this report is a very tiny step in that direction.

The Government's actions in the last month or two have shown that it has at last realised that something needs to be done. But it really is very little in an area of such great importance. We had seven long years of Minister Jones doing all he could to win over his colleagues, but he was unsuccessful. It is fair to say that no Minister has ever tried so hard and got so little or been knocked back so often as Barry Jones was while he was Minister for Science. Seeding a project such as this will get us nowhere unless we follow it through with appropriate research and development. That is very difficult. I will read a short piece of a letter that appeared in the Bulletin of 28 November 1989. Under the heading `Why be a scientist?' a scientist wrote about the future for scientists in Australia:
The Government and BHP cannot understand why the ranks of scientists is depleted and continually in decline.
He then went on to talk about three graduates who were involved:
Scientist A. Honours degree. Offer 12-18 months tenure for each position-
these were the three positions available at the time-
If we intend paying them that much, we will get as many scientists as we are currently getting. The letter continues:
The Gardener outside the window, with no qualifications, was earning $24,000.

The same scientist, while waiting for his interview and hopeful position, was earning $30,000 as a brickie's labourer. The next scientist gave up in the end and became a teacher. The third scientist, with degrees in botany, zoology and geology, was offered positions with a salary level of $16,000 to $18,000 for a 12 to 18 month tenure only. In the meantime she worked in a secretarial office on a salary of $22,000. Is it any wonder that we have trouble getting scientists? None at all.

How do we treat our scientific industries? Again, I suppose the best way to see that is to look at what our competitors do. I have two comparisons regarding scientists in other countries. One comes from an article in Newsreview on 21 October 1989 entitled `W26 Trillion set aside to boost High-Tech Industries' in Korea. The Australian equivalent of 26 trillion won is about $38 billion. The Korean Government has decided that if Korea is to be competitive in the world, it has to gear up its industries. In the fields of microelectronics, mechatronics, new materials, fine chemicals, bioengineering, optics and aerospace, the Korean Government has decided that it will spend the equivalent of $38 billion-W26 trillion-on establishing those industries over a five-year period. What are we going to do?

The alternative is what Taiwan is doing. Taiwan has decided that if it is to proceed, it too will need to develop scientific industries. To assist in that, first there will be a five-year tax holiday once a company's profits start flowing. Money will be provided at rates lower than even the modest 9 per cent or 10 per cent charged on bank loans. There will be a cash award for new equipment development in the park. There will be no need for companies to spend valuable capital on land and buildings; these will be provided on a rental basis. Entrepreneurs with advanced technical qualifications, but who lack capital, will be able to use their experience and knowledge as collateral for up to 25 per cent of the loans. What do we do in such circumstances? We do nothing.

I believe it is necessary for our Government to follow up this report with another saying what will happen later, and a further one to say what research and development will be available to get up industries with qualified people who are able to settle in Australia and able to look at a future in the technical area for years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, Small Country-Big Science, makes certain recommendations in relation to the funding of what, by any standards, would be regarded as fundamental science-$2.7m to buy a portion of the synchroton light source in Japan and thus get access to that facility for our scientists; $3.75m for the ILL facility at Grenoble in France, which is 1.5 per cent of its annual operating budget; and finally, $1.98m for the European Organisation for Nuclear Research facility, the so-called CERN facility, in Geneva, Switzerland. While I accept entirely what Senator Archer said about the poor quality of funding which this Government has given to research, particularly fundamental research, I would like to emphasise that latter point. In this country we are still finding overemphasis on the so-called applied research, on those things which will be profitable in the short run.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded that we have just passed the fiftieth anniversary of the discovery of penicillin. Some honourable senators may have heard on the Science Show last Saturday a recording made by Sir Howard Florey, a graduate of the Adelaide medical school, in which he recounted the details of that discovery in the early 1940s. He pointed out that the research team were not in any way attempting to help humanity; they were merely interested in a very intriguing phenomenon-namely, that certain substances made by moulds were able to inhibit the growth and survival of bacteria. The fact that that turned out to be incredibly valuable and produced a range of antibiotics which is probably the most widely used range of antibiotics in the world now was almost incidental.

What really drives science is the inquisitive nature of scientists to find out more about the world around us. In that sense, it is heartening to find the Australian Science and Technology Council recommending support for what, by any standards, would be regarded as fundamental science. In doing that, inevitably, one will come up with applications for that science, although that is not the thing which motivates the scientists in the first instance. On page 15 of the report we find a description of the ability to investigate, through some of these synchrotron techniques, the structure of partially stabilised zirconia and other ceramics, which have been developed by the Division of Materials, Science and Technology of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) in Melbourne. It is extremely useful in finding out something about the structure of these ceramics. Again, one finds that CSIRO has pursued research work on these ceramics because of their interesting physical property as ceramics. But quite incidentally, serendipitously, CSIRO has discovered that zirconia materials are extremely useful in the manufacture of fuel cells. It is depressing to find that having discovered that, there seems to be very little support from government for the further development of that very exciting research work. The fuel cell being developed by CSIRO would be capable of using gaseous fuels such as methane-substantially reducing greenhouse gases-would double the efficiency with which chemical energy is turned into electricity, and would substantially address many of the major problems that we face today. Yet CSIRO, looking for a mere $10m to $15m over the next six to seven years, cannot find that sort of money from this Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

upon which Senator Alston has moved by way of amendment in respect of the Superannuation Bill 1990:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) deplores the determination of the Government to support a mandatory second 3 per cent employer contribution unrelated to productivity or capacity to pay;
(b) condemns the Government for its capitulation to ACTU demands for deferred wage increases in the guise of superannuation payments and its refusal to link preservation to pension age; and
(c) criticises the Government's double standards in preferring pensions in the private sector and lump sums in the public sector''-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few further remarks in relation to the second round of 3 per cent award negotiations which are currently before the Industrial Relations Commission. I think I have already pointed out that a number of substantial defects have been assessed by very many of the major players but, of course, these have not been recognised by the trade union movement or by the Government to date. In this context I quote one comment by Mr Eric Mayer of the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd which I think is particularly pertinent in this respect. In the Business Council of Australia Bulletin in November last year, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Across the board increases in occupational superannuation, including for employees already well covered, would make little sense.

Yet that is precisely what the Government is proposing to do at the present time. In other words, it is advocating arbitrary, automatic, across-the-board increases which simply ignore capacity to pay and are likely to result in employers scaling down where they already, in some instances, have very generous arrangements in place. We do not think that that serves anyone's purposes.

I simply make clear our position regarding the current award-based superannuation schemes. The coalition is not against award-based superannuation but we do oppose, however, the totally arbitrary nature of across-the-board increases in superannuation payments as decided by the Industrial Relations Commission. We regard that as a denial of freedom of choice which has a particularly deleterious impact on small business. We oppose the second round of 3 per cent payments because we believe it would not fairly represent the circumstances and capacity of each individual enterprise and industry to pay, especially the 700,000 small businesses in Australia.

We adhere to that view, and I now espouse the approach suggested by Mercer Campbell Cook and Knight, who are undoubtedly the experts in this field, being the world's largest employee benefits, compensation and human resource consultancy. Without doubt their view is listened to more than any other in the industry. The key recommendation that they have made states:

. . . that any award should simply specify the minimum superannuation benefit which must be provided by an employer for those covered by the award. Where the employer is already providing a benefit at or above this level, there will be no need to do anything more. This will ensure any second round concentrates on providing better benefits for those who currently have little or no superannuation entitlements.

That strikes me as eminently sensible and, I would have thought, unarguable logic-except that there is another agenda being pursued by the Government. It is well known that there have been several notorious comments made in this regard that have sent shivers down the spine of many who are seeking to achieve an equitable scheme. Mr Howe, the former Minister for Social Security, made it fairly clear what he had in mind when he said:
The investment strategies of superannuation funds would be the political issue of the 1990s.
This was given full force by the Treasurer's remarks to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) Council. He said:

If the trade unions at any time are placed in a hostile political environment they will face it not only with their negotiating power in the labour market, they will face it being a significant controlling element in that $600 billion of savings.

These are the projected savings for the year 2000. That makes it crystal clear that what the Treasurer and the Government have in mind is that superannuation will become the biggest political weapon of all. If that is to be the case, very strict constraints ought to be placed on the ability of the union movement in this respect. We deplore the approach of the Industrial Relations Commission of simply taking the view, as it did recently, that somehow it is not appropriate to allow control of these funds to be left in the private sector because that might somehow encourage market forces. We think that is the high watermark of our concerns because it clearly demonstrates that industry awards are likely to be used for political purposes and that there is a great deal of scope for abuse. We believe that there ought to be freedom of choice in this area. One hopes that the Government will recognise that quickly.

We certainly think that more employees should be invited to join the boards of superannuation funds. It is quite clear that whoever is in charge is going to exercise immense power. That power ought to be exercised democratically and not collegiately, as the ACTU would want to have it at present. There is tremendous potential for abuse and we believe that the remarks of Mr Keating and Mr Howe can only encourage the irresponsible elements to believe that this provides a political market opportunity rather than a responsible economic opportunity to properly control the funds of all workers.

We take the view that this package of Bills, including the Occupational Superannuation (Reasonable Benefit Limits) Amendment Bill, heralds a new era, but also provides a great many challenges, many of which have not been met by the present Government and which I suspect, for political reasons, will continue to be unmet. That will be a tragedy for Australia. We will continue to be one of those very few countries that are prepared to provide lump sums instead of pensions. Whilst we have that sort of irresponsibility prevailing it is quite unlikely that we are going to have the sorts of policies in place that this country needs. I will give one final example. The second reading speech which was recently circulated to replace the one that went out in November last says that the Government's view is that pensions and annuities should be encouraged. In November last it was said that they were to be the preferred form of benefits. This is a very significant change. I hope that the Government will recognise that it is going down the wrong track in that and a number of other areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MACKLIN
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a number of pieces of legislation in a cognate debate on superannuation which flow from Government decisions in the Budget last year to again change the superannuation structure in a number of areas but particularly in the Public Service. Superannuation has become, in Australia's understanding of retirement, a matter of high profile and it is receiving far more recognition than it has hitherto. This is probably because of Government decisions and the following through of those decisions by various industrial tribunals.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with superannuation as part of an overall wage package. Flowing from that is the 3 per cent productivity benefit. There has been an attempt by the Government to heighten recognition within the general community of superannuation being part of that overall wage package and that is long overdue.

The traditional operation of superannuation in Australia has been one of male-dominated, high income-dominated access. It was not considered that superannuation was part of the normal expectation of the ordinary worker in the Australian community. It was considered in many ways an additional perk for those on high incomes with everyone else in the community receiving their retirement income by way of a pension. There has been a change in this general view because of the Government's move with regard to the 3 per cent productivity benefit, but I do not believe that the debate has gone far enough. The anomalies that come from our historical treatment of retirement income have not been ironed out.

The particular packages in relation to the Public Service show how one group of people can be targeted and dealt with in a reasonably straightforward way because the Government holds all the reins. But even in these circumstances, upon retirement these people can be caught up in the general context. I will address my remarks to this general context first.

The point of view of people receiving a pension and looking at retirement incomes across the board would be to say that they are badly done by for a number of reasons, one being that it has taken so long for Australian to get the pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings for retirees existing solely on a pension, and that 30 per cent should have been reached a long time ago in keeping with many of the other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries with which we like to align ourselves. They would also point to the taxation treatment of superannuation and say that a vast amount of money is lost to revenue because it is taken by people on superannuation who get a significant benefit over and above those who exist only on a pension.

The point of view of people on superannuation would be that they have spend their entire working life-as have those on a pension-paying income tax and yet when they get to retirement they do not receive a pension. They have had to look after themselves while those other people have been able to rush off and spend their money as they worked and at the end of their working life draw their pension totally out of the taxation pool.

If we consider pensions as a percentage of income tax-here I refer not only to pensions paid to aged people but also those paid to those on veterans' pensions-we are looking at between 20 and 25 per cent of all income tax receipts being necessary to support the pension payout. In a way, people could say that 25 per cent of their income is spent on providing pensions, and yet because they are superannuants-because they have looked after themselves all their working lives-they do not get a pension.

I suggest that, depending on which perspective one takes-that of a pension or of a superannuant-both those groups feel badly done by and, in a sense, both of them are. We have allowed anomalies to develop. These are historical anomalies and I do not blame the Government for them. But the Government has been in office since 1983 and it does not seem any further advanced in getting a unified retirement scheme in place.

There have been various attempts-and I am pleased to see that in recent years the private sector has made a number of attempts of its own-to put forward a reasonable and unified retirement incomes proposition. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which was chaired by Senator Zakharov, put down on excellent report in this place in 1988 but, unfortunately, except for one or two of its recommendations, it was again politely ignored by the Government. There is some excellent material in that particular report, and some excellent arguments put forward. One of the Committee's proposals to which I would like to draw attention is the long term reform option for a two-tiered aged pension system, in which that Committee seeks to marry the two systems which are currently in operation. Of course, the Government in its last Budget made a number of propositions about the taxation treatment of superannuation. It may be heading towards a unified system but, if it is, the Government has not let either this Parliament or the community in on the secret.

We do not yet know where all of these changes are heading. I believe that the Government would be well served-as would the community-by setting out a longer term framework in which these various changes are taking place. The changes have been large, they have been continuous, and they have been massively disruptive to people who are trying to organise for their retirement; yet no-one in this community knows where they are going, how they are going to be integrated and where they will end up. I think it is reasonable to ask a Government which has been in office for so long to provide to the community a unified retirement policy. It ought to provide to the community a program of changes over time and the end goal that it hopes to reach.

I am not saying that it will be able to reach that within the term of this Parliament, the next, or even the one after, because changes to these areas will take a significant amount of time. Indeed, this particular report suggests that the minimum amount of time that would be necessary for such changes would be 10 years. I think that is certainly a minimum. I believe, in terms of the types of changes which would be necessary to marry these two systems together in any adequate way, that the minimum time needed would probably be more like 20 years. To undertake such a change is, in Australia's political context, very difficult. We have three-year parliamentary terms, and we have changes of government-we have not seen one for a little while, but probably at the next election we will see one of those. In those circumstances it is not very difficult for any government to ask, `How can we plan something for 20 years time?'

I believe there is an option, and it is for us now, in this first year of the new Parliament, to start a community debate, hopefully moving towards consensus between all political parties, on the broad outlines of the way we want to go. I think that the basis for this particular debate surely must be income support for the retired and the aged, which was the subject of the Senate Committee report brought down here in 1988. It is a very good basis for that particular debate to take place. Unfortunately, as I say, a vast amount of that work has either been politely ignored or, simply, totally ignored by the Government and its bureaucracy. Nevertheless, the Government itself has not seen fit to table a program of how these things may be married together.

The Senate Committee's proposal, which I think is a good starting point, looks at the notion of the two-tiered system-that is, a universal pension payment. That universal pension payment would not be means tested and would be untaxed. It would be dealt with, as it were, as an entitlement payment arising out of taxation paid in over one's working life. That particular item would be the same for men and women; it would be based on the same retirement age and it would be a universal payment, paid to everyone regardless of their working history or circumstances.

It would be set-and I believe that the Australian community would want it to be set-at a level which enabled a person to live. It would not be generous-Australia would never be able to afford that; it would be nice if we could-but it would be a basic payment which would enable us to ensure that people would not be living in poverty, that they would have sufficient income to be able to eat and to clothe and house themselves in a way that our community expects. This community must never allow-though other communities with which we like to align ourselves have allowed it-any citizen to live in poverty. Unfortunately, we have done that. We have not significantly eroded the possibility of avoiding the worst excesses of countries such as the United States of America and Great Britain. We are in a far better position to deal with this matter.

The Senate Committee goes on to rehearse the notion that following on from that basic universal pension, set at a modest level to alleviate poverty-that would be the level of necessity, as it were-there would be a second top-up level, which would be a discretionary level, available from superannuation. That would be treated as a taxable level. It would be treated in a way that meant that, depending on how much one wished to put away through one's working life, one would be provided with the ability to maintain a standard of living commensurate with what one would wish. That would be a discretionary exercise-an exercise by which one would deny oneself a certain amount of one's income throughout one's working life in order to provide for the other end.

Of course, to enable that to work the taxation treatment must be fair and reasonable. I believe-although it is not rehearsed in the Committee's report-that we have tended to treat this in a very odd fashion. We have looked at the taxation treatment when a person receives superannuation, and I believe that the taxation treatment of superannuation ought to apply when one is paying in, not when one is taking out. The reason for that is that one is in a far better position when one is working to afford to pay the tax than one is when one is retired.

Secondly, changes in taxation treatment over time impact very heavily on people who are in retirement, who are unable at that stage to rearrange their income to be able to deal with the changing taxation treatment. I think it is a far more equitable, a far more reasonable and, in fact, a far more humanly possible operation to deal with the taxation treatment of superannuation on the payment going in rather than the payment coming out. I believe if we did that, people heading towards retirement would be able to predict much better what it is they are heading towards and could make greater allowances-and would be enticed to make greater allowances-for their retirement. Of course, the taxation treatment we have opted for over the entire period in which we have been taxing superannuation-not only under this Government but also previous governments-is to look at it as a payment coming out rather than a payment going in.

The problem we are facing in terms of the integration of the retirement incomes systems is that we really have not addressed this area as an overall policy goal in this country and we have been left with the piecemeal exercise we are confronting today, not only in these pieces of legislation but also in other pieces of superannuation legislation which will be coming down in the Budget session and, indeed, which we had in the previous Budget session.

I think the exercise is one in which we have to do a lot of things in the taxation system to get people enticed into the exercise. A predictable marrying of the pension and superannuation and predictable taxation treatment would go a long way to putting to Australians that it is in their interests to look at the topping-up exercise so that they then would become responsible for the standard of living that they have.

Indeed, from the point of view of the Medicare levy-which is able to be identified as a specific levy and which is then able to be linked via that specific levy to the outcome-if the community in general wishes for a better medical service, it can say, `We want a rise in that Medicare levy'. In other words, it cannot get something for nothing. The beauty of that is that the levy is directed quite specifically towards the outcome.

As honourable senators know, we often receive a lot of letters dealing with the levy that was started in the late 1940s. It was eventually done away with as a levy in the 1950s and, in fact, legislated out of existence two or three years ago by this Parliament. A lot of people who write to us know when it came in but do not remember it going out. It would be very useful if that exercise were started again. It is not necessarily economically efficient-which is the reason we finally abolished it-but it is good from the point of view of public policy.

A pension levy specifically designated as such, at whatever level, says to the general community, `This is the amount of money that goes out of your pay-packets every week to provide for pensions'. Any government which did that now without regularising the end product would be doing what in Yes, Minister is called making a courageous decision. It certainly would direct the attention of the Australian population to the very large percentage of their weekly pay-packets which provides for the pension. Yet a very large number of people are ruled ineligible for a pension because they have made other arrangements or are compelled-as in this legislation, which makes it compulsory for public servants-to contribute more.

By failing to unify these systems we have given rise to an enormous amount of public concern that people are being short-changed, cheated, and compelled, as in the case of the Public Service, to contribute to something to which they are already contributing. They then lose out in benefits which other people receive and which their tax pays for.

The pension system in Australia has not been a funded one; I am not necessarily suggesting that it should be. But I believe that it could be a system whereby we are able to specify the amount that is required each year from income tax to be paid for the purposes of supporting whatever pension system we believe in. I do not think it is necessary to have a funded pension system. I do not subscribe to the doomsday demographic theory that we are about to become a country in which only people over 65 live and in which there will not be anyone around to pay for their pensions. A closer reading of the demographics shows that in about the year 2020 we will be slowly approaching a stage that Europe passed through about six or seven years ago. It has been able to cope; we will be able to cope. So I am not putting forward a doomsday theory.

I believe that the unrest, concern and enormous amount of noise in the retirement income area is due almost solely to the fact that the Government has failed to state where it wishes to head over time. What does the Government believe will be the retirement income policy situation in the next 10 to 20 years? Why has the Government failed to state this? I hope that the new Ministers, who have combined responsibility for this area, believe that it is part of their policy brief to say to Australians `In 10 or 20 years we believe this is where we'll be heading'. I freely acknowledge-and I believe that anybody who knows anything in this area has to acknowledge-that to change retirement income practices is massively complex and difficult, but that does not necessarily mean that we should not point towards where we want to go and where the various changes are heading.

Are the changes piecemeal? Is this whole exercise being driven by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and not by the responsible Ministers? What goes on in Cabinet? Who takes the submissions about every one of these changes? Do they come from the responsible Minister or are they simple a revenue measure? Is there a little group over in Treasury that runs all this policy? Does not the vast bureaucracy, which supports the responsible Ministers, have a fresh idea to put to the responsible Ministers about where we should be heading or what we should be doing? From the point of view of public debate, I believe that we need at least one of the responsible Ministers to take this thing by the neck and give it a good shake-to be willing to get out there and generate a public debate about this whole area.

I am not denying that it is matter for the Treasury. There are enormous financial implications in any change that takes place in this area. It is an extraordinarily costly area, and every change has massive implications for revenue and for the way taxation is dealt with. Obviously, the Treasury will have a very large input. But that is not all. We also have to look at policy. For example, in Singapore people pay a significant portion of their income to support their retirement. A number of years ago a policy decision was made to allow people to take out of that retirement income package a significant proportion on the proviso that that money be used now for housing. That is an interesting idea. It is an interesting policy. We could look at how the policy is developing in Singapore, at whether it is a good idea.

Considering our interest in Australia in and public support for housing as part of our lifestyle, to look at Singapore is an excellent idea. But we cannot do that because we do not have any government or anyone at all willing to stand up and say, `This is where I believe we should be going; this is the overall objective that we should be moving towards'. The private sector has started to do that. What is the Government's ultimate objective? Instead of outlining this, Bill after Bill comes into this place tinkering here, tinkering there, moving a bit of tax around, shoving this aside and changing that. From the point of view of public policy, it is unsatisfactory; from the point of view of retirees, it is totally unsatisfactory; from the point of view of those people who are trying to plan for their retirement, and who want to know where all of this is going and how they should decide, it is absolutely impossible.

When the statement was introduced by the Government in the Budget session last year, Senator Janine Haines indicated on behalf of the Australian Democrats that we would be supporting these changes. We do support them. We believe that the package deals with a problem area that had to be tackled. I think that the overall compromise that has been reached between the Government, the public sector unions, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and other negotiating groups is a good one. There are elements within it which some groups are not happy with but in terms of the compromises that are necessary in any of these areas as an overall package I think that it hits the mark. Some significant benefits are provided for the public sector and, in terms of the difficulty that Australia is heading toward by way of public sector remuneration, the changes make eminent sense.

A popular Australian pastime is attacking the bureaucracy-that probably goes along with the popular pastime of attacking politicians-but if we are going to be able to provide a proper standard of advice to government, proper administration by government and proper accountability by government to the Parliament, we will have to have top quality people in our public sector. The public sector is out of kilter with the private sector. The difficulty in dealing with that matter has been borne in on all honourable senators over the last year and a half. I know that it would have been borne in on certain Ministers who have to try to negotiate their way around the current impasse. This superannuation exercise is part of the overall package that we now believe is necessary. The idea of income is not simply what income a person receives in his pay packet every second Thursday in the Public Service, but rather the total remuneration over a work period.

I believe that this has been a good exercise. Unfortunately it has one aspect that I think is taking us in the wrong direction, and that is the lump sum preference that certainly appears very strongly in this legislation. I have talked to individuals in the community about where they would prefer us to go and they have said that they prefer the lump sum payout. I am not saying that the Government is not taking on board what its clients are interested in. However, I am concerned, from the point of view of public policy, that we should be setting up a mechanism, suggesting that it might become a pacer, which is heading in direct contradiction to where we need to be going in terms of a unified policy structure. Whether people like it or not, the pension option is the only viable economic option for Australia in the long term. We cannot deal with a unified system which has as its first preference a lump sum payout. It is just not possible. It might be nice; it would be lovely if we could actually do it. But it is not economically feasible or possible to set down a unified system that has that as its major exercise. We constantly have to get out into the community and win the argument.

I return to the major issue I wish to raise in this second reading debate: unless there is in the Government's mind-hopefully this is shared with the electorate-a unified retirement income program that will require all of us to deal with this issue over time, then we cannot get out there and argue to the people why we need a pension option instead of a lump sum option. Unless the Government provides this as part of the public debate, I think we will lose constantly on this exercise in the public arena.

The Government has failed us on two grounds: firstly, the public policy option has not been articulated and debated; and, secondly, in this flagship, as it were, it has gone for the soft option-the lump sum. I think that will come back on us in the next 10 or 15 years and we will rue the day that we allowed this to occur. I do not think there is any other way of doing this at the moment because of the failure of the Government to win the rather broader public debate of the pension option.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appeal to the Government: we have put certain proposals about anomalies in this legislation. Would it be possible to have a specialist Minister who has some knowledge of the background of what we are putting forward to respond in the appropriate way? We do not have the time available to debate this matter and to keep referring it back to the appropriate Minister. Would it be possible either to have the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) or the Minister responsible for the legislation in the chamber at present?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

For that reason I have asked that that occur and I am assured that fairly shortly the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will enter the chamber, and I will be very happy when he does.
