SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will leave the contentious issue-I believe that there are very serious anomalies that should be corrected-until the arrival of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). In the meantime I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), who is at the table, to pass on my remarks. The last time the Government introduced extensive amendments to superannuation schemes, it drew the lines of definition for superannuation funds, pooled superannuation trusts and approved deposit funds (ADFs) and imposed a set of conditions which were based on whether they were complying or non-complying funds. The level of compliance with those conditions exposes such schemes to certain levels of tax. We understood that the basic reasons for the underlying conditions would not change, but in the legislation before us today the Government introduces a new element of uncertainty that will fundamentally change the status, particularly of ADFs.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments at that time also covered the entry to superannuation funds and withdrawals on retirement or early withdrawals. The position was either exempting or subjecting certain payments to various levels of tax. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC), which was the regulatory body, had the responsibility of formulating regulations to meet these new statutory obligations. We have no problem with that at all. After the last round of changes to the superannuation legislation and regulations about two years ago, I remind the Government that the Treasurer, Paul Keating stated:
Together, these changes complete the Government's review of superannuation tax arrangements.
People can therefore plan for their retirement with complete certainty and confidence.

That is a very clear statement to the Australian people. This is the finality, apart from finetuning. We have before us today something which goes well beyond finetuning so that, in spite of this, changes to superannuation laws continue unabated. So far there is no such thing as complete certainty or confidence in retirement planning. The sooner this Government settles on a retirement incomes policy for this country, the sooner the country will reap the benefits of such a policy.

The legislation before the Senate today covers four Bills, the Superannuation Bill 1990, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Bill 1990 and the Occupational Superannuation (Reasonable Benefit Limits) Amendment Bill 1990. I think it is a pity that these Bills are being dealt with cognately. As Senator Macklin said, he ran out of time in dealing with the extensive changes that are being made. In the space of 30 minutes we are dealing with major changes to Commonwealth superannuation and to reasonable benefits legislation.

Three of these Bills resulted from a review of the current Commonwealth superannuation scheme. The other Bill refers to reasonable benefit limits. The Superannuation Bill 1990 introduces a new Commonwealth superannuation scheme for most Commonwealth employees from 1 July 1990. While I support the principles on which this Bill is based-that is, that Commonwealth employees should have the same regulations and restrictions as the rest of the work force-I believe it is hypocritical of this Government to introduce lump sum superannuation arrangements for its own employees but at the same time promote pension-type schemes for the private sector.

Less than two years ago during the extensive parliamentary debate on superannuation Bills, Ministers repeatedly expressed their disgust at double dipping. By double dipping I am referring to the practice of lump sum payments being taken by retirees, they then spending their money, and at a later time taking a pension benefit from the Government. If the Government were not just giving lip service to the double dipping problem but instead wanted to address this situation, it would not have drafted this legislation which allows Commonwealth employees to take all benefits in a lump sum form and thus ignore the recommendations from the social security review unit and others. The Government is introducing legislation that runs counter to its philosophy and to what it said two years ago in trying to force the private sector into pension-type schemes, contrary to what the social security review unit and others said. That is quite hypocritical.

The Government stands condemned on three counts for the way and the manner in which it has drafted this legislation. The social security review unit said that at least half of all the supportive benefits should emerge in pension form. We agree with that; it is quite reasonable. But no-the Government has chose the other route. We admit, however, that there is a generous conversion in the scheme for a lump sum to a pension. But the fundamental structure of the scheme is wrong because it is geared to a lump sum rather than a pension scheme. In other words, it is structured to the wrong goals.

While undoubtedly popular with the unions, the Government's approach goes against the thrust of what we refer to as a responsible retirement incomes policy which ought to promote increased reliance on a guaranteed stream of earnings in lieu of the aged pension. The Minister for Social Security would be acutely aware of the need to follow this dictum.

Public servants who have a second income and are in a position to make a higher contribution levy to the fund are also in some circumstances-and this is an anomaly because the Government is not treating everybody as equal-able to lift their contribution from 2 per cent to about 10 per cent and get a better benefit. What could be more inequitable than not to treat everybody in the Public Service on a like basis, simply because some are born with a silver spoon in their mouths and others are not so well off? Some people can get some extra benefits in the form of a retirement benefit.

I might say, at this time, that I welcome the presence in the chamber of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, who has the ability to acknowledge some anomalies in this legislation and, hopefully, he will do something about them. It is wrong in principle that not all people are treated equitably. I endorse the amendment to be moved by my colleague Senator Alston that seeks to lift the minimum rate from 2 to 5 per cent. This amendment tends to ameliorate some of the criticism that I have put.

I appeal to the Government to remove the iniquitous tax on superannuation contributions. Entry to a superannuation fund, in terms of payments coming from the employer, now attracts a tax of 15 per cent. If that were changed and the income of the fund were taxed, additional funds would be released for investment which this country desperately needs. This would also release thousands of people associated with the administration and collection of this money. Superannuation administration would be much more cost effective, provided that we adjusted the tax on the incomes of the funds. So what we are putting forward is a mechanism not to reduce the total tax collections but to make sure that this process is administratively much more cost-effective and efficient. This arrangement would certainly produce a simpler and fairer scheme which would make superannuation much more attractive and would increase the level of savings.

On a much more positive note, I am pleased to see that there will now be a major improvement in what we term resignation benefits, particularly in light of the fact that two-thirds of members of the current scheme receive no employer benefits because they resign before entitlement. I think this is quite iniquitous. Similarly, the aligning of the invalidity benefits more closely to age retirement benefits, plus the establishment of a Commonwealth Superannuation Board, will hopefully reduce the invalidity rates of the current scheme from their unacceptably high levels.

Invalidity rates for Commonwealth employees are presently five to 10 times that of the private sector. If this mechanism that we are putting in place today does not work, I appeal to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) to ensure that the scheme receives further attention and further revision at an early opportunity. After all, one of the major selling planks of the new scheme is that it will cut out this high invalidity rate.

I also approve of the substantial elimination of significant indirect discriminations against women under the present system. I note that the Minister for Finance has qualified the amount of elimination. I would also suggest that unless all discriminations are eliminated, female Commonwealth employees will not be in a fund that has the same regulations and restrictions as the rest of the work force, and the principle will not be met.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a matter raised by my colleague, David Connolly, who was the former Liberal shadow Minister for social security and retirement income. Commenting on womens' superannuation in the publication Securitas, he said:

The Government's attempt to overcome the major discrimination against women in regard to Superannuation is unlikely to be successful because it only covers women who work for at least 10 hours per week and does not offer proposals such as retirement savings accounts . . .

Honourable senators might recall that this was a proposal put forward by the Opposition, designed to encourage such women to move into superannuation. It provides a simple mechanism which will assist people in their retirement. In other words, the Government expects women, who are disadvantaged people in terms of the superannuation arrangements which currently exist, to use conventional methods of superannuation which have proved inadequate in the past. There have to be innovative changes. We have to recognise a situation where women can leave the work force after two or three years. At the present time, husbands do not receive tax deductions for contributing to their wives' superannuation in such circumstances. This is a matter that needs to be acknowledged. The only women who will benefit from the proposals that the Government is putting forward are those women with professional qualifications on a relatively high income. The vast majority of working women will gain nothing from Labor's alleged reforms. So women on low incomes-say of $15,000-certainly will be disadvantaged.

The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 makes a number of changes to various superannuation Acts to reflect the changes associated with the proposed introduction of this new Commonwealth scheme. I note the comments made by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to the effect that clause 39 contains numerous examples of sexist language and, in its view, this is inappropriate and, accordingly, the provisions should be redrafted. Again, the government of the day has failed to acknowledge the major recommendations of an important committee which has a majority of government members.

I endorse the amendment which will be moved by my colleague Senator Alston. Whilst welcoming the opening up of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust to competition and allowing it to compete in the open market by providing investment services, we have to limit the authority to the funds of Commonwealth, State and territorial bodies.

I would like to raise some major problems, commencing with proposed new section 15f of the Occupational Superannuation (Reasonable Benefit Limits) Amendment Bill. We have major problems in that superannuation funds are dealt with differently compared with approved deposit funds. It seems outrageous that a superannuation fund can be fined or receive a penalty of up to $15,000 yet an ADF does not attract that same penalty. Rather, an ADF's status can be changed from that of a complying fund to that of a non-complying fund and the people who would have been victims are beneficiaries.

I put to the Minister that the simple way is to have equality. If people are in a superannuation fund they must be subject to the same traumas as those who are in an ADF. Similarly, if the Government wants to put a $15,000 penalty on the superannuation company, why does the Government not apply that same penalty to the administrator of the ADF, the trustees of the ADF or the fund itself? But, for heaven's sake, do not take away its status.

When the Government introduced this notion of complying and non-complying funds and ADFs two years ago, it gave us an assurance that there would be no fundamental change from the underlying conditions or status of these respective bodies, and there was a long debate about it. We need to be able to plan for people's future security and long-term operations, and here, less than two years on, the Government is introducing a destabilising element to the basic concept of complying and non-complying funds.

It is so important that I will go through the relevant proposed new sections 15f, 15g and 15s just in case we do not have time later. We are quite prepared to delay the committee stage of this debate so that this matter can be examined and rectified. We are quite happy for the Government to bring the matter forward as its amendment. We should delay the committee stage of this debate so that the Government can take further advice to ensure that we deal fairly and equitably with all classes of people where they happen to invest in superannuation funds vis-a-vis ADFs. Honourable senators should not tell me that people have more opportunity to avoid the law, et cetera, in one as compared with the other.

We appeal to the Government to delay the committee stage of this debate in order that it can go back and discuss the matter with the ISC, the Taxation Office and others to ensure a better basis for inflicting a penalty than exists in this legislation. Honourable senators should not come back in two years and say, `It was an unintended consequence; we will adjust it by a miscellaneous statute law provision or something else', because in the meantime the Government will have done a lot of damage to a lot of people and a lot of funds. We have got to get it right, and we have got to do it now.

The requirement is to advise the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of amounts held by individual members at 15 April 1990, and the information is to be provided within such reasonable period after 1 July 1990 as is prescribed in such form as is approved in writing by the Commissioner. Penalties apply for failure to advise. So the industry is in the dark as to what and exactly when the information is to be supplied. For a life office, the penalty is $15,000 for failure to comply. The ADF will lose its concessional tax status and become a non-complying fund.

Under proposed new section 15g the payers of ETPs, which are eligible termination payments, and pensions are to provide certain information to the ISC within the lodgment period. Again, penalties apply for failure to advise. The penalty for failure for a life office is $3,000. It can go up to $15,000 under the Crimes Act. However, the failure of a superannuation fund or ADF to comply will make them non-complying, which is unduly harsh and unreasonable.

Under proposed new section 15s the excessive proportion of an annuity or pension can be commuted within one month after receiving advice from the ISC. So will the commutation be able to be made by life offices or the fund? The life offices are liable to a penalty of $15,000. Once again, the fund becomes non-complying. All members of a superannuation fund are penalised which, again, just seems quite unreasonable. Apply the penalty to administrators and trustees, but do not change the status from a complying to a non-complying fund, thus altering one of the essential tenets of this distinction which the Government introduced only two years ago and which was supposed to be fixed in concrete at that time.

The Occupational Superannuation (Reasonable Benefit Limits) Amendment Bill seeks to amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1967. I have already referred to some problems I have seen with the Bill in relation to reasonable benefits. We are not opposed to the thrust of what the Government is putting forward. In fact, we have just received some amendments. These amendments seem to be in order, except that we are a bit surprised at the wording in relation to the identity of a person. The word `or' is used instead of `and', but perhaps the Government will take that on board and give us the reason for that unusual distinction. So we basically support the Bill, with the reservations that I have put forward, together with the amendments that Senator Alston has moved in order to overcome some of the unusual or worst features of that Bill.

The Commissioner of Taxation and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner previously restricted the benefits that could be provided by superannuation Bills, and the effect of this Bill will be the establishment on 1 July 1990 of reasonable benefit limits as to the amount of benefits a person is permitted to receive on a concessional tax basis. Previously, it was the maximum amount that could be paid out of a superannuation fund. So there is a fundamental shift, which appears reasonable to us. So with very limited exceptions, the reasonable benefit limits will apply to all concessional tax benefits regardless of whether those benefits are provided by public or private sector sources, whether they are provided by superannuation funds, roll-over funds or employers, and whether they are funded or unfunded. We are attracted to that, because everybody is being treated equitably. It is, therefore, all the more unusual to find the circumstances in proposed sections 15f, 15g and 15s when the Government is trying to get this sort of uniformity across the board and all the more surprising that the Government has come up with a lump sum scheme rather than a pension scheme.

Superannuation funds will be permitted to pay out higher amounts of benefits provided that amounts in excess of the limits are included in a person's taxable income and are taxed at the appropriate marginal tax rate. So these changes are designed to redress the longstanding inequity of private sector superannuation benefits being subject to limits while public sector benefits were exempt-again, a commendable approach and one that is overdue.

So we support the Government's decision to calculate reasonable benefits limits on the basis of the highest average salary over any three years before retirement rather than the average of the last three years, because a person in those last three years might not necessarily be in his peak earning performance. In latter years he could be phasing down his responsibilities in the organisation with a view to somebody else taking over. I believe that this will encourage people to stay in the work force longer and gradually reduce their work commitments while at the same time giving the benefit of their experience rather than to retire in their mid-50s when they feel that their earning potential has peaked.

So providers of concessional tax benefits will be required to advise the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner of the prescribed details of benefits provided to individuals, and we have no objection to this. But we object to the penalties that apply in terms of the distinction between the different sorts of funds. I think that we have put a reasonable case to the Government to amend the legislation before it is too late and gets set in concrete and while the House of Representatives has time to consider this on Thursday or Friday and send it back to the Senate, at which time we will have a complete, tight package rather than the thing strung over for two or three years.

So the ISC will be required to determine the amount of the benefit paid to the person that is within the reasonable benefit limits and the amount of the benefit. There is no problem if any are in excess of the limits prescribed under the regulations. To assist the Commissioner to administer the limits effectively, the Bill proposes that, where a person is paid a benefit subject to the reasonable benefit limits, that person be permitted to provide his or her tax file number for forwarding to the Commissioner. There will be no compulsion to provide the tax file number, but where it is not provided the benefit will be reduced because there will be a requirement to deduct tax from the benefit at the top marginal rate.

Provided the ISC is satisfied that such a requirement does not breach the principle of 1 (a) (i) in terms of the reference and does not unduly trespass on individual rights and liberties, the coalition basically supports the provisions within this Bill. In relation to the changeover from one system to another, the word `change' has already spread to many constituents who have made retirement plans under the previous law and now have to face another set of laws. In fact, many representations were made to my office. I believe that the Government's change of date from 15 August to 15 February is a welcome one and will satisfy a lot of people who had deferred their retirement and suddenly got caught with this date of 15 August, finding themselves up for additional tax. I am pleased that at least the Government recognises the strength of the representations that were made to it about the need to change this date, given the assurances that were previously made when people who delayed their retirement suddenly got caught as a result.

I believe that the objective of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in reforming the retirement income policy as per the four Bills that are before us today is to significantly increase the role that occupational superannuation plays in Australia's retirement income arrangements. That raises an interesting point. Whilst the pressure is being placed on moving savings away from banks and into life assurance offices, it does seem surprising to see the Treasurer's changing approach, for example, in disallowing the merger between National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd and the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. The Government is forcing the mode of changing in Australia, which will eventually put a lot of pressure on mutual life offices because of their lack of a capital base and will tend to send the banks overseas for expansion rather than within the Australian area.

Unfortunately, superannuation has become another maze for a public to find its way through. We have a plethora of rules and regulations which has resulted in a system which is now so complicated that it is beyond the range of ordinary John Citizen to comprehend. Australians are increasingly being forced to rely on superannuation advice from the advisers within the market. In many cases they do not know until they retire, until it is too late to do anything about it. Unfortunately, these regular changes that we are having to superannuation legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson finished his speech by talking about what he regarded as the strategy behind this legislation. SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Macklin's qualification with regard to paragraph (c) of the amendment to the second reading motion moved by the Opposition, let me say that my present understanding is that there is no double standard in preferring pensions in the private sector and lump sum payments in the public sector. As I understand it, the majority of private sector schemes provide lump sums. What the Government is doing here is no different from what a very wide range of private sector schemes do. If what I have just said is incorrect in any way, I certainly hope I will get a note from the advisers on my left which tells me that I am wrong, but I do not think I am wrong. If that is so, the third paragraph is incorrect. Senator Macklin, who does not agree with paragraphs (a) and (b) of the Opposition's amendment, will be relieved of the burden that he currently has in respect of paragraph (c).

It has been claimed that the change in respect of the Commonwealth legislation to a lump sum scheme is inconsistent with a sensible retirement income policy. As I understand it, there has been a dramatic growth in deposits with approved deposit funds and annuities in recent years, which suggests that lump sums are considered an important vehicle in terms of making provision for retirement. Certainly, it is the Government's view that lump sums are a legitimate form of retirement benefit.

The question one would ask rhetorically is: why should Commonwealth employees be denied the opportunity to take their benefits in a lump sum form, because lump sums give the employees much greater flexibility to arrange their affairs in a manner which suits their particular needs? The current pension scheme for Commonwealth employees means that the employee who supports parents, brothers, sisters or adult children cannot always make adequate provision for those dependants in the event of his or her death. Simply stated, a lump sum scheme will enable the Commonwealth to match the benefits being offered in the private sector, thereby enabling the Commonwealth to attract and retain competent staff.

In terms of the retention and attraction of competent staff to the Commonwealth Public Service, there is no doubt just from the public debate-certainly there is no doubt in my mind as a Minister-that that has been an enormously difficult task in the last few years because, amongst other things, of the very high salaries offered in the private sector, salaries which often go with so-called packages which include superannuation benefits. The Government's policy is to permit lump sums but to encourage pension benefits at the same time. This new scheme is consistent with that policy.

I remind the Senate that the scheme has a very attractive pension option as well. The subsidy in the pension option for those retiring early is greater than the subsidy at older ages, thereby giving more encouragement or incentive to early retirees to take pensions. For example, if a member converts at least half of his or her benefit to a pension then he or she gets the advantage of the higher reasonable benefits limits that apply in such cases. The possibility of lump sums being dissipated has been incorporated into the costings of the current new schemes. Of course, the Government has had to be concerned about the question of costs-that there be no increase in net Commonwealth superannuation costs. The new arrangements meet this requirement.

The scheme also enables members to contribute between 2 and 10 per cent of salary according to their financial circumstances from time to time. This was another issue raised in the course of the debate. The Opposition suggested that employees might contribute only at the minimum rate of 2 per cent of salary throughout their membership.

The scheme design provides for a greater subsidy for the employer as the member increases his or her contribution. That is an inbuilt incentive in terms of the level of the employer contribution and an incentive to the employee to increase his or her contribution. This encourages members to increase their contribution when financial circumstances permit. It also enables those who leave the work force for a time, for example, women raising a family, to be able to achieve adequate benefits from shorter service.

There will also be greater counselling under the new scheme which will advise members of the advantage of contributing more towards their retirement. This is considered purely as a supplementary mechanism. After all, it was Senator Watson who made the point that these things were difficult for people to understand. It is a very appropriate area for counselling, in addition to the various incentives which are built in to the system in terms of contribution levels.

Some honourable senators made remarks about expanding the charter of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. The Government considers that that is necessary. For example, a range of government business enterprises which currently have employees in the Commonwealth scheme are setting up their own schemes. Telecom Australia is the largest example, and it will be setting up its own scheme from 1 July 1990. Australia Post will also have its own scheme. The Trust will have to compete with the private sector for the investment of the schemes being set up by these government business enterprises. The Trust will face further competitive pressure in five years time when it loses its statutory monopoly over the Commonwealth scheme. The Trust needs a wider client base if it is to be able to meet this competition. Without the capacity of the Trust to compete for private sector funds it faces increased risks of managing a declining fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —So do most businesses.

—Not in this area. A declining fund reduces the capacity to spread the risk and allocate assets optimally across sectors. If the Trust is restrained in its capacity to compete, as has been implicitly suggested by some contributors to the debate, and fund performance is worsened, there will be a direct adverse effect on the 100,000 employees expected to remain in the current scheme after the changes to which I referred a minute or two ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The new Commonwealth scheme pays a guaranteed pre-defined benefit and any underperformance by the Trust will mean that taxpayers will have to pick up the extra cost. That is the reason for the need to expand the charter of the Trust and place it in a more competitive environment. If performance is adversely affected, subsequent broadening of the Trust charter may be too little, too late, and the damage may be irretrievable. Without mentioning specific examples, that is something which other governments in other jurisdictions, as it were, have found to their cost in recent years with some of their own schemes-not necessarily with superannuation schemes, but honourable senators will use their imagination and know what I mean.

The new Commonwealth superannuation scheme represents a significant step forward in superannuation for Commonwealth employees. It provides additional flexibility; it makes membership available to all Commonwealth employees; it makes an equitable contribution to the retirement of all employees according to their service in the Commonwealth; and, importantly, it puts Commonwealth employees on the same footing as their private sector and State counterparts. That seems to be a matter about which there is some misinformation leading to dispute as to the facts, but in the Government's view that is beyond doubt. Moreover, the proposed new scheme will cost the Australian taxpayer no more in net terms for existing employees than the current arrangements, with longer term savings.

Some Opposition senators deplored the Government's support for a second 3 per cent superannuation benefit-that is, of course, referred to in the second reading amendment-and claimed that the Government had double standards on lump sums and pensions. That is referred to in paragraph (c) of the second reading amendment.

I do not want to end with political point-scoring on these issues, but let me make the point that in all the years that the coalition was in government nothing was done to encourage the provision of superannuation for ordinary citizens in this community or to ensure that superannuation benefits were used for retirement. I guess the problems associated with a relatively ageing population have come into sharper focus in recent years. For anybody with any long term informed view of the matter, that knowledge was available at least a decade ago. Under the present Government the opportunity to receive superannuation has been made available to most members of the work force. The self-employed have been encouraged to make provision for their retirement and that encouragement has led to increased provision.

There have been mechanisms put in place to enable employees changing their jobs to preserve their superannuation benefits and these are being used for genuine retirement. Pension and annuity benefits have been encouraged without removing the free choice to take lump sums, which is something that I mentioned earlier in my remarks. Higher reasonable benefit limits have been made to apply where at least half of the benefits are taken as pensions.

Senator Watson raised what was, for me, a rather technical question about the higher reasonable benefit limits legislation and I will try to obtain an answer for him as soon as I can. I think there is an answer but perhaps I should not try to articulate it without help. I appreciate that it was a serious point. Finally, under this Government lump sum benefits are now taxed on a comparable basis to superannuation pensions.

The Opposition, while outwardly espousing pensions, still talks about removing the tax on lump sum payments. But there is equity in the superannuation pension treatment that has now been there for some time. So the Opposition talks about the ageing of the population, implies a need for greater superannuation coverage and criticises Government support for the next round of 3 per cent superannuation.

Paragraph (c) of the Opposition's second reading amendment, which talks about double standards, I think could be applied to paragraph (b) of its amendment as well. There will always be opposition from one quarter or another to benefits flowing to the work force. There is no opposition from thoughtful employers to benefits flowing to the work force in this way, rather than benefits which flow straight into the effects of the wages system on the levels of inflation which are, as the Opposition always points out, somewhat higher than we would like them to be in this country at present.

I have taken longer than I normally would. I will try to obtain an answer to Senator Watson's particular questions relating to the fourth Bill. The Government rejects the second reading amendment because we do not think it is right. In terms of paragraphs (a) and (b) we do not think it is sensible. With respect to paragraph (c), we think it is wrong. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to move an amendment in relation to the schedule contained in Part 3, Division 1, on page 82 of the Superannuation Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 82, The Schedule, Part 3, Division 1, rule 3.1.2, Rate of contributions, leave out ``that is not less than 2 per cent, and not more than 10 per cent, of the fortnightly contribution salary applicable to the person. The member may'', insert:
``that:

(a) in the case of a permanent employee or a permanent full-time employee, is not less than 5 per cent and not more than 10 per cent, of the fortnightly contribution salary applicable to the person; and
(b) in the case of any other employee, is not less than 2 per cent and not more than 10 per cent, of the fortnightly contribution salary applicable to the person.
The member may, subject to this rule,''.

The essential proposition is that the Government has previously had a Commonwealth superannuation scheme which provided for a minimum-and, indeed, a maximum-employee contribution of 5 per cent. We take the view that in certain circumstances that has been an arbitrary figure, but nonetheless it has been very desirable that there should be a significant minimum level of contribution on the part of employees. The rationale put forward for this more flexible approach, so described, is that representations are received from time to time by employees who argue that because of their present financial circumstances, it is somewhat difficult to maintain that level of contribution and therefore they ought to be given the opportunity to scale down in some circumstances and to scale up at a later time when it suits them.

As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) rightly pointed out, there is a built-in incentive to keep the contribution as high as possible because that will determine the level of support that it attracts from the employer. Nonetheless, if the overall objective is to come out at the end of the day with a reasonable figure of about $175,000-plus, it is necessary for the employee contribution to average at least 5 per cent over that employee's working life and, indeed, probably in combination with the employer contribution, to get up around the 12 or 13 per cent mark.

Our concern is that if we allow people to contribute only 2 per cent, there will be an irresistible temptation to come down to that figure, because of the exigencies of life and what seems to be an immediate crisis, and once the crisis has passed there will still be reasons for staying at that lower level. People do not tend to review their superannuation contributions on a monthly or even yearly basis; they turn their minds to it very occasionally, fix on a percentage and leave it in place.

Senator Button and the Government might argue that there is plenty of scope for counselling, but I think it would be a very cost-ineffective way of doing business if we are going to have to contact 150,000 Commonwealth employees on a regular basis-in particular, those who have scaled down to something around the 2 or 3 per cent mark-and then call them in for an interview and try to persuade them that they ought to do the right thing by themselves and their families and go up a bit as circumstances dictate. All of that is very messy and likely to be ineffective.

We take the view that the rate ought to be a minimum of 5 per cent. That has not worked a great degree of hardship, I would have thought, in the past under the present Commonwealth scheme. There may well be means by which the Public Service Union or others might be able to accommodate those who have genuine emergency situations, and maybe there should be scope in the legislation to countenance that sort of discretion. But to allow a blanket reduction to 2 per cent whenever people feel like it is inviting people to do just that.

Therefore, we think there is a very real prospect, with this degree of flexibility, that people will not average the 5 per cent plus over their working lives but will simply take it in the form of a current wage increase. After all, this was the selling point to the Australian Council of Trade Unions in many respects-that if people were allowed to come down by the 3 per cent, then they would be much more attracted to it. Undoubtedly the attractiveness lies in that very proposition-that they will see the opportunity to reduce their payments, to therefore have more discretionary or disposable income in hand and, presumably, feel that they are somewhat better off in the short term. We all know how people's short term horizons tend to dominate the long term. There is no reason to imagine that this will be the grand exception simply because the Government or the Opposition might wish it to be otherwise. Human nature, I think, very much suggests that people will find all sorts of plausible reasons to justify contributing only that lesser figure.

We therefore think that if people are on about a responsible retirement incomes policy in the public sector, when we have moved dramatically away from the former compulsion to taking at least a proportion as a pension, the very least we ought to be doing is retaining that compulsion in terms of a respectable minimum contribution. Accordingly we therefore move the amendment, which has been circulated in the name of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say `the employer'.

—I will stay with that as I was on safe ground at that particular stage. The employer, in fact, then also raises the amount paid in. So there is a very real incentive for people to raise their contributions from 2 per cent to 5 per cent or possibly to 10 per cent once they have the disposable income to do so. I imagine that hitting the 10 per cent level is not likely to occur until well into a person's working life.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also somewhat concerned in terms of the distinction drawn between permanent and temporary workers. Within the permanent exercise we have permanent part-time and permanent full-time employees. I am glad that the Opposition has not sought to make a distinction between full-time and part-time employees but only between permanent and temporary employees. In terms of the temporary category, we can have a temporary part-time or a temporary full-time employee. I would not wish, in any way, to seek to make a distinction between these people in terms of what they might be able to do. In fact, there has been an anomaly for a long period against temporary employees, particularly those who have been employed full time over a long period but as temporary employees. For example many people who are now at retiring age have never been able to get into a superannuation fund. I point, for example, to quite a number of the people who are engaged in the Commonwealth car pool. Many of those have only in recent times been able to come into any fund because, for some arcane reason within the Public Service, they have all been designated as temporary, despite the fact that they have been employed full-time-some of them have driven cars for 30 years. I think it is important that we treat those temporary people in the same way, as though they had made an election to enter the scheme and the election had been accepted in terms of the rules set down in this particular scheme. But on the grounds that, firstly, I do not see a reason for making a distinction between permanent and temporary employees and I do not think that Senator Alston has spelt out a reason why we ought to make that distinction, and secondly, because there may be some disincentive put in the way of temporary people electing to come into the scheme, I think that we should give the proposition a chance to operate. At a later stage, if the take-up by those who are able to take it up is less than satisfactory, I am quite sure that the Government, in terms of its own monitoring, will look at it.

I think this has probably been argued in terms of that total package that I spoke about during the second reading stage. I think it should be left that way and, in terms of consultations that I have had with the various unions, it is certainly very much their desire on behalf of their own members that it should be left that way. I think that they have good arguments to leave it there. I do not see the argument on the other side as compelling and, hence, I will not be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal briefly with a couple of remarks made by Senator Macklin. We distinguish between full-time and part-time employees on the basis that those in part-time employment may well have more pressures or more obligations placed upon them and may not be able to structure their contributions in the way that permanent employees are able to do. I will look at the arithmetic to demonstrate why we think that it is unlikely that, having gone down to the lower level, someone will turn around and go to the higher level. Average earnings I think are about $27,000, but let us say that someone is earning $30,000. The contribution of 2 per cent of that amount would be $12 a week. If it were to be 10 per cent, it would be $48 a week. There is a very significant difference between those two amounts and I find it difficult to imagine that anyone would voluntarily come to the judgment that he or she should turn around and contribute an extra $36 a week simply because, some years down the track, he or she might reap a greater benefit as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: The overwhelming temptation is likely to be, as I suppose 90 per cent of the community find, that, as people's expenditure patterns exceed their incomes, at the best of times there is always a good reason why they are not able to save a bit more. We want to encourage savings and we want to do it in such a way as to ensure that people come out at the other end with a decent level of provision for their retirement. We believe that that gap is simply too great and that, as such, it is not likely to induce people, having fallen to the 2 per cent contribution rate, to raise it to anywhere near the 10 per cent at any particular time in their lives because there will always be a reason why they cannot afford to do it at that time.

I think that $12 a week from salary of $30,000 is a fairly small contribution to make. Conversely, the gap between $12 a week and $48 a week can be quite significant. It certainly involves some level of sacrifice and, unless someone is persuaded to make that sacrifice, in a sense almost beyond their inclinations, it is highly unlikely that that person will do it voluntarily. That is why we think the Government has simply taken the easy way out.

I was very interested to hear what Senator Macklin said in his closing comments about the unions being strongly opposed to it. The reason why the unions are strongly opposed to it is that by being part of the wage-tax trade-off and in exchange for their getting, thanks to this Government over the last seven years, a continually declining standard of living and, therefore, a reduction in their real wages, they will be able to pick up an extra 3 per cent virtually for nothing because the 5 per cent that they were previously contributing can now become 2 per cent. So if they are short of a quid or they want to somehow justify getting into this deal in the first place, this is the way they will do it.

It is no wonder that they are very keen on the 2 per cent rate because that is the way they will go. That is what their employee members have been told they can do. It does not strike me that there is any built-in responsibility in that sort of proposition. If the overwhelming proportion of the public sector are permanent full time employees, they are the ones who will be scaling down and who will not be maintaining that necessary average over time. The part time employees-although I suppose their numbers are increasing-nonetheless constitute a relatively small proportion of the work force and we are prepared to allow them that additional flexibility because, by definition, they cannot predict their working patterns and the demands placed upon their incomes in the way that permanent full time employees can. But if we are expecting some measures of responsibility-in a sense, it is implicit in the minimum 2 per cent contribution rate that the Government expects them to have a certain level of responsibility for their futures-we do not see why that level of responsibility ought not to be one at which they will be able to come out at the other end with the sort of money that the Government says is necessary in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Committee on this. We did have the same technical objection, which has largely been solved by Senator Alston's amendment. This is a question of judgment. Senator Alston has by implication given us a lengthy treatise in the behavioural sciences, suggesting how people will behave in different situations. I am not sure that we know that.

SPEECH.PARA: This scheme is designed to have some flexibility, and that flexibility is designed to be influenced by the incentives to which I referred to earlier in terms of the employer contribution. As Senator Macklin put it-I quite agree with him-people should live in a democracy, and the question is how guided it ought to be. As individuals, people will have the ability, particularly if they are low income earners, to adjust contributions to other financial commitments such as young families or mortgages at appropriate times in their lives. I would have thought that by and large, public servants, in spite of the somewhat derogatory remarks made about counselling earlier on, are in a better position to do this than most people in the private sector. I think superannuation has always been a consideration in public sector employment. Public sector employees are probably more aware and astute about the issues which concern their through-life incomes and superannuation than many in the private sector.
So the amendment is not acceptable. It is, in our view, too rigid and not justified by the arguments which have been put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Bill as a whole in committee. Would it be desirable to dispose of this amendment one way or the other before I raise another matter?

—It would be preferable for the focus of debate. When this amendment is dealt with, I will put the Bill as a whole, either as amended or as it stands, to the Committee, and you can debate whether any other aspect of the Bill is in order.
—A number of honourable senators have received petitions relating to the reserves of $428m of contributors' funds. The petitions read:

SPEECH.PARA: The undersigned contributors of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme hereby respectfully petition and request the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund to distribute a RESERVES of $428 million to contributors (including contributors who have resigned since the announcement of the 1988 review of the fund) as follows:
(1) Actual payment of entitlement to contributors who have resigned since the announcement of the 1988 review.
(2) Actual payment of entitlement to contributors who resign in the future.
(3) Notional distribution to all members transferring to the new fund as at 1st July 1990 for the purpose of calculating contributor equity holding in the fund.
The undersigned indicate that they deplore any attempt to:
(a) Deprive contributors of rightful allocation of their funds.
(b) Deprive resigning contributors of their former and rightful benefits.

Those petitions are signed by quite a large number of people. They are petitions which were not addressed to the President and the Senate, but I think it is appropriate for them to be brought to the attention of the Committee at this stage. It does appear, as indicated in the letters that have been received by honourable senators, that there is quite a deal of concern about the proposed treatment of the reserve of $428m held back by the fund administrators from distribution to members on the division of the fund under the new arrangements proposed by the Government. A reserve of that magnitude has been set aside as:

a `cushion reserve' to artificially bolster the earning rate of the Fund in times when it is not as it should be. It could therefore be used to hide administrative ineptitude as well as raise the earning rate in time of economic downturn.
I quote from the letter that was sent to me and I believe to some other senators:

The creation of the reserve has been at the expense of current members and will be used to benefit future members. The funds administrators have `robbed Peter to pay Paul'. This situation is clearly grossly inequitable. The reserve is currently approximately 8 per cent of the value of the members holding in the Fund. This means that some long standing members of the Fund could have a stake of between $6,000-$8,000 in the reserve.
This inequity will be exacerbated on the creation of the five new funds as spin-offs from the Main Fund.

It is intended that the reserve will be distributed between the funds on a pro-rata basis. This will clearly be inequitable because each member's stake in the reserve is a unique sum attributable only to each member and will be a different unique sum for each individual-not an average struck by an all embracing averaging calculation.

If the reserve were to be transferred it would carry elements belonging to members of the old Fund. If a large number of older members chose to remain in the `old' Fund they would be subsidising the reserve amounts transferred to the `new' funds.
This, the elector says, is outright robbery. On the face of it, it does appear to be such. It appears to be utilising the contributions of people over many years, to their ultimate detriment.

I was wondering whether there is an answer which the Government may wish to place before the Committee at this stage. I assume that the Government is well aware of the concerns that have been expressed by persons who have petitioned the superannuation fund. I do hope that the Government might be able either now in the committee stage of this Bill, or indeed in the committee stage of subsequent Bills, to outline its view on the subject and to allay the concerns of those who have expressed them to a number of honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can probably help Senator Harradine. The policy in respect of the reserve was reviewed in 1988. At that time private sector actuaries provided advice about the policy and the amount of reserve. Essentially, the reserve is used to stabilise the earning rate of the funds. If there is no reserve, either the earning rates swing markedly or investment is likely to take place far more conservatively which reduces members' benefits in the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing abnormal about this occurring in the Commonwealth field. Large private sector funds have reserves. The reserve in respect of this Commonwealth scheme has existed either explicitly or implicitly for years. I can understand that the document from which Senator Harradine was reading was presumably motivated by some concern or uncertainty, or it may have been motivated by some certainty that it was a good time to put one's hand out. Whichever way it was, I hope that clarifies the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 24, paragraph 24 (a), lines 25 and 26, leave out proposed subparagraph 29a (1a) (a) (iv).
Page 24, paragraph 24 (a), line 31, leave out proposed subparagraph 29a (1a) (b) (ii).
Page 24, paragraph 24 (a), after proposed subsection 29a (1d), add the following new subsections:
`` `(1e) Nothing in the functions of the Trust shall be taken to provide the Trust with the authority to deal with funds other than the funds of a Commonwealth or Territory body.
`(1f) In this section ``any funds'' means any funds of a Commonwealth or Territory body.'.''.

The amendment that has been circulated is a composite amendment designed to restrict the activities of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) because we believe that what the Government has in mind with its amendment is to give the Trust more than it is taking away. It is going to have monopoly control of not only the continuing superannuation scheme but also the new superannuation scheme for five years, after which time it will be out in the real world and competing against a number of private sector-

TALK.START.PARA: —A good sort of Thatcherite description, isn't it, Senator?
—If the Minister wants to jump to those sorts of cheap characterisations, he may. I would have thought level playing fields were supposed to be what he is all about, but this is tilted very much.
—You are the big talker about Margaret Thatcher in here.
—I do not recall mentioning her name for quite some time, but it is obvious that that is what makes the Minister twitch so we will see what we can do for him in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: We take the view that there is no particular reason why the Trust ought to have that monopoly now. I have not heard advanced any plausible reasons why there might suddenly be some instability if it were exposed to competition. Indeed, that could be phased in if necessary. I am sure Senator Button could enlighten us as to all the good reasons why the trust needs a five-year break, but to allow it immediately to get into the business of investment and management advice across the board, public and private sectors, domestic and international, seems to us to be a very far-reaching extension of its powers of operation.

Again, no good reason has been advanced for why the Trust should suddenly be regarded as having that sort of expertise. Undoubtedly, it would be on a learning curve and the justification supposedly is that it needs to have the opportunity to earn more moneys in these areas to compensate for the likely loss of business five years down the track. There are some assumptions built into each of those propositions. The first is that the trust will inevitably lose market share in five years time. I suppose that is overwhelmingly likely, but it does not follow that it will lose it on other than the merits. It is likely that it will lose it because there are better players around with a greater degree of competence and who will therefore be able to put together better deals. If that is the only reason why it will lose market share, it does not deserve any particular protection or special advantage.

What the Trust is being offered by way of compensation is the ability to roam far and wide here and abroad. I would have thought that if we were interested in ensuring that people stick to their knitting, the last thing we would want to do is encourage a public sector instrumentality to go off and acquire instant expertise around the world. There is no particular reason to suggest that all those markets are not being properly served with the time. It smacks very much of the picking losers mentality which governments, both Federal and State, have adopted in recent times. The rationale of bodies like the Victorian Economic Development Corporation or the Victorian Investment Corporation Ltd, State government insurance offices or other comparable instrumentalities, is always that somehow they need to broaden their base, they need to get into general insurance, they need to try to make a quid on the side and that there is no reason why they ought to be discriminated against.

Recent history suggests that there is a very good reason they ought to be discriminated against, if that is what it is. The reason is simply that they lack the competence. They are not exposed to the sorts of commercial pressures which will inevitably drive efficiency in the area. No-one pretends that the private sector outcome is perfect every time. Of course, there will be failures for all sorts of good and bad reasons, but there is nothing like a bottom line to concentrate one's attention on the real issues. That simply does not apply in this area.

I would have thought that there was no logical justification for allowing a public sector instrumentality to get out and compete in the wide world unless it was simply to enable it to gain experience. If it then becomes simply another funds manager or investment adviser, we have to ask the question: why is it in the public sector at all? If we are going to be told that this is an interim proposal and that Senator Button for once-I suppose twice if we count the fairly small percentage for the Australian Industry Development Corporation-is about to have a win on the privatisation front, I would be very interested to hear about it, but I am sure we will not be given any such public rationale. Therefore, if we are talking about an instrumentality that will remain indefinitely in public hands I do not understand why it should be given that sort of free kick.

There is no reason to suggest that the market is being improperly served at the present time and there is no reason to suggest that those seeking advice will somehow be better off as a result of getting it from SFIT. Therefore, I would argue that it ought not to be going out into that arena at all; it ought to stick to its last. But certainly the felony ought not be compounded by giving it that five-year monopoly holiday at the same time as it has instant access to the rest of the world. We therefore take the view that a one-sided approach is being adopted and that it may be in everyone's best interests if the trust is simply restricted to what it has been doing for a considerable period of time; that is, maintaining its investment and managerial advice to the public sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: (5.17)-Senator Alston's comments were a wonderful mixture of `sticking to knitting', `staying with one's last', `compounding the felony' and `keeping a level playing field'. I will just stay with one of the analogies, that of the level playing field which, I must admit, I have never been too fond of, considering the fact that they are the ones that always get boggy and that some slope on the playing field is always highly desirable. Anyone who has ever had the misfortune to construct a playing field would know that one with a slope always has a slight advantage with respect to drainage. That is why teams change ends. So the idea of the level playing field has never attracted me much as an analogy.

SPEECH.PARA: But the propositions ought to be looked at; it is a serious point. I sought to discover what precise advantage the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust might have. It is an extraordinarily small one, all things considered. By and large, in terms of overseas equity and a number of other such items on which it may be seeking to give advice, the Trust would not have any advantage because all charges which would be applicable to a private fund would also be applicable to a government fund.

The Trust does have some advantages, certainly, with regard to domestic equities because of the stamp duty exemption with regard to a Commonwealth instrumentality. It remains to be seen whether this is the Government's intention or whether the Government has some other view with regard to this particular body. But the stamp duty exemptions which would apply with respect to domestic equity would have to be incredibly small, in any event. On any reasonable estimate, in the period to which we are referring we would not be looking to anything of very great moment.

A stamp duty exemption would apply when the investment fund gives advice on property. With regard to wholly owned property only-because it does not refer across to share mixes-it is possible that the Trust would be exempted from land tax. There would be the possibility of a stamp duty exemption in rural areas; of course, rural holdings are exempt from land tax.

All in all, a very slight advantage is given to this fund in the way it operates, mainly stemming from a stamp duty exemption. But one has to take into account whether this exemption assists the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust to gain business. As a general rule, those types of exemptions would not be able to be transferred because the client's funds are managed on a discrete basis and hence would not get mixed up in the actual operation of the trust fund. So they would not, as it were, leap across the boundary from the trust fund to the clients' funds.

On the basis of the assumptions I have just made, the effect of the continuing exemption of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust performance really would be quite immaterial. On the basis of the calculations I have had made, less than 0.1 per cent effect on the rate of return would be based on the current level of funds under management. Consequently, a client would be highly unlikely to select this particular Trust as a fund manager on that basis. The selection of the Trust as a fund manager would be made on a far more substantial basis than that. If any of the funds in which I have money were to make a decision on that basis I would be very upset. One is looking for a far more substantial return.

I have another concern. Senator Alston's amendments attempt to exclude the fund from seeking this particular business. If it were another matter, Senator Alston and I could well have swapped sides. This could well be characterised as a deregulatory exercise, in which I am normally on the other side. Presumably, Senator Alston ought also to be in support of this deregulatory exercise. I do not support it because of the implications for the taxpayer. Under this new scheme, in relation to the payment of a defined benefit, any underperformance by the Trust represents an additional cost to the taxpayer. The Commonwealth is responsible for the difference between that defined benefit and the sum of the member's contribution plus interest earned thereon by the fund. I hope that that particular fund is a good investor. If it is, then the taxpayer ought to be happy.

Senator Alston referred to the fact that-as we know from the reading of the Bills and the previous exercise we went through here-government business entities will no longer be required to have regard to this Trust to manage their funds. I hope it is such a good fund that it will attract that business, but since many of those government instrumentalities are likely to offer less attractive propositions, it could very well be that it will not.

We have to be very careful about this exercise. We are moving from a monopolistic situation to a more open one. It is prudent to be conservative and to suggest that we have this additional ability and that we also have a screening off of the fund over the five years. We should allow this fund to operate. We should be prudent in the way we make these types of changes. I hope that at the end of the five years we will see a vigorous Trust which is well able to compete. Until that time I think it is prudent to do this.

It is also prudent in terms of a reasonable proposition that I will put to Senator Alston: If this fund is out there in the real world that Senator Alston referred to in competition and seeking further income, then it will be in a far better position to engage in that more open market in five years time.

It is prudent that there be a transition from this type of fund. They have to develop expertise. I remind Senator Alston that they are up against some pretty formidable Australian performers. We are very lucky to have those very good performers-Australian owned mutual companies-that have done exceptionally well in the open marketplace, not only in Australia, where they have somewhat of a captive audience, but also overseas. To be able to compete against those formidable performers will require the acquisition of expertise. That expertise cannot be acquired at the end of five years; it has to be done over time. People have to build up confidence in the operation of the Trust. The Trust has to know what it is doing. Hopefully, when we get to the end of that five-year period this additional income support will have given it that edge so that it can compete.

All in all, the Government has operated in a very prudent fashion. It has been mindful of what we are dealing with and mindful of the fact that the taxpayer would have to pick up the bill if we were not doing it. I am not too sure that the trust fund will get too much business in the early years. I hope it does, but I think that the money that will come in will very much go to supporting that acquisition of expertise needed to put it in a position to compete against the private sector in a real way in five years time.

I do not want to pejoratively put the view, as Senator Alston has. I think the Government has put a reasonable proposition before us. We are prepared to allow it to operate in the way it has been set down. The Government has been mindful of quite a number of factors. All in all, I think it is the best way to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to one logical conclusion that seems to come out of Senator Macklin's last comments: that is, if he wants to give the fund the expertise-in other words, over the next five-year period to learn how to behave in the private sector-it will presumably be on a Commonwealth funded learning curve for the purpose, Senator Macklin would argue, of being better placed to hang onto the business, over which it will have a monopoly now but not in five years time.
—It won't have it very soon-in July.
—It will have a five-year monopoly.
—No, not in respect of other government instrumentalities like Telecom.

—No, not the other government business enterprises (GBEs). But for the new Commonwealth scheme it will have a five-year monopoly. SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the Government is saying, `We hope it will be able to learn sufficiently over the five-year period to be able to cope when it is exposed to competition down the track'. Implicit in that is the suggestion that it is not coping at the moment and that the beneficiaries in the funds are getting less of a good deal than they ought to be getting. On the merits, the Government would not expect the fund, with its present level of expertise, to be able to provide as good a result as the private funds, but hopefully in five years time, when it has been able to get out there and learn a bit more, it will be able to compete. If that is the logic of the argument, it seems to me that those contributors ought to be entitled to get a good deal from day one as those in the government business enterprises (GBEs) presumably will be getting a better deal from day one. The Trust will be able to provide investment services on a fee for service basis, either discretely-
I do not know whether that is meant to be spelt `discretely'; if it is I presume it will be done very quietly, which is not the way business is normally attracted in a very competitive area-

I ask the Minister in relation to those last words whether legal advice has been obtained-that is, as to whether there is any constitutional doubt about the ability of this Parliament to provide for the extension of the powers of a public sector entity to give advice with respect to the management, the investment or the management of the investment of any funds or any funds held in trust for the benefit of any other person or body: in other words, absolutely everyone. Is it hinged on the corporations power or is it in some other way not a matter of doubt? It seems to me by including those words `as is constitutionally possible' that there is an implicit concession that there may not be constitutional power.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is getting the State governments to deal with it.
—Is it simply that? If it is that, where do we get the power to override State governments in this respect?
—Complementary legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very briefly. I thought Senator Macklin dealt with most of the points and I certainly spoke on some of these points in my response to the second reading debate so I do not want to indulge in a common practice here of boring people.

SPEECH.PARA: The essential points to make include that, sure, the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust will be exposed to further competitive pressures in five years time, when it loses its statutory monopoly over the Commonwealth scheme. As from 1 July, as I pointed out by way of interjection, Telecom Australia and Australia Post will have their own schemes and the Trust will have to compete immediately with the private sector for the investment of the schemes being set up by these government business enterprises (GBEs).

In that context the Trust needs a period if it is to be able to meet this competition. It needs to widen its claim base. In all fairness, it should be given the opportunity to widen its client base in the marketplace having regard to those circumstances which I have just described. We are putting the Trust on notice that in five years time it must have a capacity to compete for private sector funds, otherwise it will be faced with the risk of managing a declining fund. That is relevant not only to the management fund but also to taxpayers. Those are the main points I would like to make.

There is nothing unusual about the behaviour of the private sector in the marketplace. From Senator Alston's former incarnation of shadow Minister for communications he will recognise that a lot of people in the private sector come to Ministers-and undoubtedly Opposition spokesmen-and say something similar to, `Aussat ought to be privatised, but not yet. It should be made a profitable organisation by the Commonwealth before it is privatised'. I know that is not a good analogy in relation to the Trust but it is a precise example of the private sector saying, `Make this a golden cow before we have a look at it'. We are saying that the bronze calf-which is this particular Trust-should be protected intact and have the opportunity to improve and to widen its client base over a period of time, which we think is totally logical.

The only other matter to which I have to respond relates to whether legal advice has been obtained about the constitutional power in relation to the wide range of activities-one might call them advisory activities in a generic sense-which the Trust may embark upon. I am advised that legal advice has been obtained and that the provisions are drafted in accordance with that advice. If the Trust or any Commonwealth instrumentality of this kind wants to disallow these State government powers, it cannot be done by overruling, it has to be done by complementary State legislation. That is one aspect of the constitutional problem. On the basis of legal advice, one or two areas of proposed activities of the Trust might have to be tested in relation to private sector participation by the Trust. That is by no means certain. Senator Alston knows what legal opinions are like. As I understand it those areas are at the fringe. The Government will not accept the amendments for the reasons we have indicated on three occasions now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister about just one further matter: why are government business enterprise (GBE) employees to have the opportunity to get better deals than they might otherwise get under the Commonwealth scheme and, conversely, why should public sector employees be forced to a lesser entitlement if that is the likely outcome? One proceeds on the basis that whilst Telecom Australia and Australia Post might be GBEs, they are still in the public sector and this Government has no intention of privatising them. Presumably, there is likely to be a difference in terms of superannuation remuneration or there would be no need to have a separate scheme. TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston cannot have it all possible ways, with respect. Only half an hour ago Senator Alston was arguing that employees under the Commonwealth scheme should not be granted lump sums. Now it seems he is putting a totally different position.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM (AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA ZONE OF COOPERATION) BILL 1990PETROLEUM (AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA ZONE OF COOPERATION) (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Cook:
