TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990 was dealt with in the House of Representatives on 14 May when the Opposition moved a second reading amendment outlining our concerns with the Bill in its then form. Those concerns related to two things: firstly, that the capitalisation grant should not be capable of being used as start-up grants; and, secondly, that there was a possibility of double dipping.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to those two issues specifically, the original Bill was not sufficiently clear in our view in providing that the capitalisation grants could not be used as start-up capital. Those grants, in our view, should not be able to be obtained for yarn production capacity that did not already exist in the industry. The Opposition sought an assurance that to receive a grant the applicant must be a producer of bountiable yarn and must have lodged a claim for bounty, and that the making of a capitalisation grant be limited to expected bounty receipts in respect of existing capacity. The Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr Beddall, gave such an assurance. In respect of double dipping, under proposed new section 21f of the Bill the coalition is now satisfied that any debts arising out of unfilled obligations by the recipient of the grant to the Commonwealth are reasonably well covered, with the exception of the case of bankruptcy and sale which could result in double dipping.

The Opposition sought an assurance on this concerning control. Minister Beddall in the committee stage of the Bill accepted the validity of our concerns, as we had expressed them in our amendment and having introduced amendments stated:

. . . the Government has accepted the concern expressed by the Opposition that the Bill does not completely protect the Commonwealth from the possibility of having to outlay money for a capitalisation grant, and then, subsequently, having to outlay additional money for a legitimate bounty claim in respect of bountiable production for that which the grant was meant to disentitle.

The Minister accordingly introduced amendments to the Bill which are now incorporated into the legislation as it presently is before us. Thus the Opposition is not moving in the Senate the second reading amendment which was moved in the House of Representatives, and we are not so doing for two reasons. Firstly, as to the question of start-up capital, the Opposition is satisfied that the undertakings given by the Minister that this scheme will not-and, indeed, cannot-be used to supply start-up capital for new or expanded capacity will prevent any such abuse of the new system. Similarly, the Opposition accepts that the altered wording in the explanatory memorandum gives teeth to this undertaking. With regard to the question of double dipping, we consider that the amendments moved by the Minister, as set out now in the legislation before us, are successful in preventing double dipping and satisfy our concerns.

The amendments moved by the Government in the other place ensure that ministerial control over identified essential assets is strengthened by the additional provision denying bounty entitlement to any subsequent owner who uses such identified assets to produce textile yarn. It is interesting, I think, to look at the Bill as it comes before us in terms of how the scheme was devised and, indeed, came to be presented. It seems to have arisen from a review of the textile yarn bounty administration, but that review could perhaps be called a review you have when you are not having a review.

The background is this. In a letter to the Chairman of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority dated 24 January 1989 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) sought the review of the textile yarn bounty administration, but made this extraordinary statement:
The review should not embrace assistance levels to yarn producers but should be restricted to an examination of yarn bounty administration.
The terms of reference of the review stated:
The review will exclude examination of programmed levels of assistance accorded yarn production under the TCF plan.
How one can make a proper assessment of the bounty scheme without considering the level of assistance to producers is not really clear but, as stated in a discussion paper by the Authority:

No effort was made by the Authority to review the merits of textile yarn bounties compared to some other possible forms of assistance or to consider varying the overall level of budgetary assistance accorded the yarn production sector as part of that policy.

The report of the review was supposed to be submitted to the Minister by September 1989 but only a discussion paper was ever released and a final report has yet to be forthcoming. The discussion paper may very well have led to the drafting of the Bill which is before us, but one wonders whether the final report will ever be released.

The discussion paper did, however, show up some quite interesting statistics. Firstly, it shows that bounty assistance to the industry generally amounted to some $250m in 1988-89, of which textile yarn bounties accounted for 35 per cent or $86.9m. Secondly, it shows that the annual nominal expenditure on textile yarn bounties has progressively increased from $23m in 1981-82 to $86.9m in 1988-89. Real outlays peaked in 1985-86 prior to the full effect of the 20 per cent Budget reduction on all bounties. Thus since 1981 the Commonwealth has outlaid a total of $588m in bounty assistance to the yarn sector.

The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority conducted a survey of 78 per cent of bounty claimants, representing some 97 per cent of total bounty outlays. Some 90 business reporting units, representing 121 registered factory premises, responded to the Authority's survey. Again, the findings were interesting. The survey found that 30 per cent of recipients received less than one per cent of the total value of the bounty-that is, 27 companies received less than $50,000 each-while 17 per cent of recipients received more than 81 per cent of all bounty, that is, 15 companies received over $1m each.

When the textile yarn industry is analysed by large manufacturing groups it is found that the five largest groups account for 72 per cent of the total bounty. Thus, although the discussion paper presented us with some interesting material, I think it is nonetheless important to comment upon the fact that, in the Minister's terms, the Authority was restricted to an examination of the administration of the bounty without ever looking at the comparative advantages of the method of assistance that was being given. So one can only conclude that perhaps the Bill as it is before us, that is for the capitalisation scheme, has grown out of discussions that have flowed from that discussion paper.

One can also ask oneself whether or not this is to be a one-off venture. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill seems to make it clear that this need not necessarily be so. It was asked of the Minister in the House of Representatives whether the capitalisation grant concept would be extended beyond textile yarns. Mr Beddall replied that he was not aware of any plans to do so but that the option of capitalisation would undoubtedly be considered if this scheme proved successful.

The attraction of the Bill to the Opposition, and the reason that we are not opposing it, is that it offers three positive things. It offers an alternative assistance scheme for textile yarn producers which, in turn, will offer a reduced Commonwealth expenditure, accelerated restructuring of the industry and reduced dependence of the industry on Commonwealth assistance. That is the intent of the Bill and it was for those reasons that Mr McLachlan in the lower House said in his speech to the Bill that we do not oppose the thrust of the Bill if it does what it implies. So the concerns that were raised by the Opposition in those early stages dealing with those questions of double dipping and start-up capital have been adequately dealt with.

There are one or two other issues that may be important to deal with when we reach the committee stage of the Bill in order to follow up some of the questions that were asked of the Minister concerning undertakings that were given. I will do that when we proceed to that stage of the Bill. As I said, the Opposition is not opposing the Bill because we see that it offers those three important points: reduced Commonwealth expenditure, accelerated restructuring of the industry and the possibility of reduced dependence of the industry on Commonwealth assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990 and, as the previous speaker, Senator Bishop, has said, this Bill is not a particularly controversial one, and it has the support of the Australian Democrats. It seeks, very broadly, to amalgamate the bounty, which may be paid to textile yarn manufacturers over some years into the future, into a capitalisation one-off grant so that those textile manufacturers may be able to improve the manufacture or marketing of their products and become more efficient and, therefore, more cost effective in the manufacture of their products. In that respect, the Australian Democrats support this legislation and believe it is certainly a step in the right direction.

SPEECH.PARA: It hardly needs to be said that in many areas of the textiles, clothing and footwear industry Australia desperately needs to gain a great deal more value added to its products. A very large amount of our wool clip is sold, as we hear all the time, in its raw state; a very small amount is processed. Similarly with the other products in this area, a large amount is exported without a great deal of value added. To the extent that these capitalisation grants will encourage the development of value added to build more efficient industries, they will very significantly improve the industry overall and improve Australia's position vis-a-vis other countries.

The payment of a bounty or the charging of a tariff does raise another interesting area which I think is somewhat vexed and which has not been particularly well handled by the Government, from a philosophical point of view. There has been a wish by the Government progressively to remove tariffs on the grounds that, in a very simplistic view, price is a sufficient measure of the efficiency of a particular industry.

To shift ground just momentarily, I will use a recent example. I was in the Riverland during the last election and the citrus growers were particularly concerned about the progressive removal of tariffs from imported citrus juice from Brazil. They pointed out, and I believe quite rightly, that in Australia we have introduced a number of measures to protect workers in that industry and to protect the environment in the production of citrus and citrus juice. It is quite unfair to import product from another country which does not observe the same standards of occupational and environmental health.

It would be quite appropriate to structure a tariff or a bounty that properly reflected the costs borne by Australian industry when faced with that sort of competition, which does not suffer the same imposition of costs in relation to the protection of its workers or its environment. I make that point in passing because the textile industry in many of its applications has also exposed its workers to quite substantial risks-and I will mention one of those later on-in relation to cotton spinning and weaving. So when these costs are borne by Australian industry because we have imposed those sorts of controls, it is appropriate that it be protected from foreign competition if that competition does not meet the same standards of occupational and environmental protection.

This Bill seeks to allow the capitalisation of the bounty which will be payable to manufacturers in this area. To obtain a capitalisation grant it will be necessary for a manufacturer to prepare an application and for the application to be assessed. Then a grant may be made. The Bill sets out that one of the principal considerations is that the total cost of that capitalisation grant brought back to constant dollar terms is less than the bounty that would be paid.

One interesting feature of this Bill, which I found a little bit surprising, is that there may be many situations in which the amount of money required to upgrade a particular textile activity is substantially less than the amount of bounty which would be payable. There is no provision within this Bill for a continuation of the payment of a reduced bounty so that the total amount-that is, the capitalisation grant plus the bounty-finishes up as roughly the same amount of money. I can understand why that is done, but it may be-I just suggest that this may be the case-that some applications may be for larger amounts than are actually required on the grounds that the manufacturer in question may see it desirable to seek a larger grant than is absolutely necessary, simply to get the full value of the bounty which would otherwise be paid.

I understand that the amendments which I will be moving will be circulated. As the Government has accepted those amendments, I would simply like to deal with them now to save time later on because I believe that they are not controversial. The Bill as it is before us is framed in such a way that the costs and other benefits are assessed within the industry alone. In other words, the benefits of the improvements in the manufacturing process which might arise as a result of a particular grant being given are assessed against the costs and if the benefits exceed the costs and the overall cost is less than the bounty that would be paid, presumably a grant may well be made.

This is the way cost-benefit analyses are often done, and often done to the detriment of the externalities which arise in manufacturing processes. This has been particularly true in a number of the textile industries. One may look back to the dark days when asbestos fibre, for instance, was being woven into fabrics. The consequence of that was a very large increase subsequently in lung diseases and lung cancer. Clearly, the cost of that in terms of human ill health, in terms of treating those people, should properly be borne by the industry that was responsible, the industry that initially sought to weave that asbestos fibre.

Unless honourable senators think that asbestos is an unusual example, I mention the disease called byssinosis which arises with those who are involved in cotton weaving and spinning, a disease which crippled many thousands of people in the United States because of the inhalation of small pieces of cotton fibre which produced a similar, chronic progressive fibrotic disease of the lung similar to that caused by asbestos.

If the changes in the technology which might arise as a consequence of one of these grants should, for instance, increase the amount of fibre in the air and, therefore, increase the risk to workers, increase the number of people who might subsequently suffer from these chronic fibrotic diseases, then, of course, those costs which economists like rather interestingly, to call externalities, should be internalised and those costs should be taken up in the assessment of the grant. We hope that with modern technology there will be an improvement not only in the cost efficiency of production but also in the quality of the air in factories where this activity is carried out.

An example of externalities in relation to the environment in general would be in the case of the proposed wool scouring plant in the Albury-Wodonga region. This was proposed several years ago. Many people were concerned that the effluent from this wool scouring plant would eventually find its way into the upper reaches of the Murray River and lead to an increase in pollution similar to the sorts of pollution we saw last summer. That would be another example of quite a massive external cost, which would have to be borne somewhere else in the community should such a plant ever be established under those circumstances. Again, the size of that external cost would be dependent upon the nature of the wool scouring that was carried out. In other words, to some extent it would be dependent upon the particular technology chosen.

It does not take a great deal of imagination to understand why these external costs need to be internalised. In that way the overall costs and benefits to the community of this changing technology which might result from these capital grants would be assessed. Accordingly, I will be moving two amendments in the committee stage which relate to the content of the application by the proposer and also to the way in which that application will be assessed, so that both the occupational and the environmental health and safety aspects arising from the changes will be taken into account.

I believe the Government will accept those amendments. I do not wish to speak to them. I think they are adequately covered here. The Australian Democrats are very pleased that the Government has seen fit to accept them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990. I will develop the reasons why such a bounty is seen to be necessary and desirable at this stage. It is often said that Australia is non-competitive. Why is it said that Australians are inefficient when clearly in many cases that is not so? I wonder whether this is based simply on the international price. Is it based on the productivity per person per hour, or is there any element of national significance, value adding or allowing for special cases? What really constitutes efficiency under those circumstances?

SPEECH.PARA: Costs come under two headings. There are costs of production and social costs. Much of the first category is common wherever the goods are produced, while costs vary considerably from country to country and have nothing to do with efficiency and affect only a section of the overall economy. We have to check only a sample of our social costs to see what I mean. All of these have developed in highly prosperous bygone days. We now have them all and seem likely to retain them-whatever the cost in the future.

First, our cost of labour. It is not that our labour cost is the most expensive in the world. What becomes expensive is that only 77c of each dollar paid in labour goes into the cost of production. In 1986-87 for every dollar of labour costs paid by Australian manufacturers 77c were for time worked; 12c were paid in respect of leave, bonuses, termination and severance pay; and 11c for other costs such as payroll tax 4.3c, superannuation 2.8c, workers compensation 3.8c, fringe benefits 0.4c, and so on.

Australian labour costs are high in comparison with those of some of our competitors in this region. For instance, they are about 50 per cent higher than those in New Zealand and four times higher than those of Taiwan, Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore. On an index basis where Australia is 100, the United Kingdom is 96, New Zealand is 65, Taiwan is 24, Singapore is 24, Korea is 23 and Hong Kong is 22. Those figures were compiled by the United States Bureau of Labour Statistics in March 1989.

However, when we look at this list, included in Australian production costs would be 20 working days holiday per year-or 30 days in many cases-10 working days cumulative paid sick leave per year, and 10 public holidays per year, which leaves us with a working year totalling 220 days at best, or 66 per cent of all of the days of the year. We have equal pay, higher junior rates, overtime, penalty rates, fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, company tax, payroll tax, workers compensation insurance, superannuation, wages indexation, maternity leave-or, in some cases, paternity leave-child-care arrangements, and so on. I am not saying that I object to any of those and I am not saying that other places do not have a variety of them also, but I do ask whether other places have them all and whether we can afford them all, anyway. That is all part of the cost of everything we produce. Is that what we call a level playing field?

Let us consider how our producers get on competing with others when the value of our dollar is 76c, when interest rates are 17 per cent to 20 per cent and when inflation rates are 8 to 9 per cent-miles above those we must compete with on cost. The dollar value on a trade-weighted basis between June 1985 and March 1990 shows a fall of 8 per cent while comparison with the United States dollar shows an appreciation of 13 per cent-or in the wrong direction by 21 per cent.

The value of the Australian dollar has been propped up by high interest rates and has been necessitated by a chronic current account deficit and the consequential need to attract capital flow from overseas. Between June 1986 and March 1990, costs as measured by the respective rates of inflation rose in Japan by 2.3 per cent and in Australia by 33.2 per cent. Yet in the same period the dollar appreciated against the yen. The yen was 110.96 to the dollar in March 1986 and 118.79 to the dollar in March 1990. The adverse impact of this situation on Australian manufacturers competing against Japanese imports can be illustrated best in the following simple example. In June 1986 an Australian manufacturer produced an item for $100 and was able to compete in price terms with the Japanese production with a landing cost of $100 or 11,096 yen at the prevailing rate of exchange. Assuming prices move roughly in line with inflation, by March 1990 the cost of the item was $A133.20 or 11,351 Japanese yen. At the March 1990 rate of exchange that represents $A95.56, so the Japanese import is now almost 30 per cent cheaper than the previously similarly priced Australian product.

Who pays for this? It is the productive sector which pays. For those who are lucky enough to earn and spend on the one market, it does not matter. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I will not go through the whole schedule but I will just mention a couple of items from it. It shows that, as a percentage of the total imports in 1982-83 as against 1988-89, whereas we imported 15.7 per cent in the selected items in 1982-83, we are now importing 24.4 per cent-an increase of 55 per cent in that period. In 1988-89 the value of imports was about $11,500m. Had we controlled our figures, we would have saved $4,000m just by the extra goods that we are now importing. Simply closing down an Australian industry and buying from overseas will solve nothing in the long term but will create yet another crisis in the short term. As honourable senators realise, it will increase our imports, pump up our dollar value and interest rates even further, and encourage increased overseas ownership of Australian property and equity. Is that what we want?

SPEECH.PARA: Why does the community at large expect the dollar-earning, internationally competing productive sector to bear all of this while the non-competing sector has very little concern about what those indices are? For anyone who is, say, a member of parliament, a baker, an accountant, a bricklayer, a grocer, a doctor, an optometrist, a taxi driver, a sharebroker, a banker, a clothier, a newsagent or a hairdresser, and with no competition from similar occupations in Singapore, Taiwan, Korea, Spain, Brazil or wherever, there is no problem. But those who produce shoes, prepared foods, books, clothes, cars, crockery, electronics, et cetera, are in trouble through no fault of their own-through nothing that they have done but totally because of what Australian society at large has decided the productive sector will pay for.

For those who are not in that group, does it matter what are the rates of pay, the holidays, the fringe benefits, et cetera in any of those industries in other countries? Of course, it does not. But please think about this. Do those who are deciding how to cut back on industry and export promotion understand what other countries with which we compete very solidly do for their industries? In the Australian of 16 March there was an item about Taiwan. If one tries to get an industry started or to make one go in Taiwan, the articles states:
First, there will be a five-year tax holiday once a company's profits start flowing.

Then the Government, which has pumped more than $US300 million . . . of its own money into the scheme, will make available through its Bank . . . money at rates lower than even the modest 9 or 10 per cent charged on bank loans here.
There also will be cash awards for new equipment developed in the park.
None of the companies need spend valuable capital on land or buildings-these will be provided on a rental basis.
Nor will they have to build a warehouse-the Government will provide one in the park complete with full Customs services.
In 1990, the companies in the park will together produce revenue of $US2.1 billion.
The 1996 target is $US6 billion, almost all in the form of exports.
How are we competing with those sorts of things? In the Newsreview of 21 October 1989 an article about what Korea is doing states:
The government will pour 26 trillion won (about $38.81 billion) into fostering the seven frontier industries over the next five years.

The high-tech industrial fields which it expects to lead the nation's economy in the 1990s are microelectronics, mechatronics, new materials, fine chemicals, bioengineering, optics and aerospace . . .
It then goes on to say:
The country's share of the world high-tech market, 1.4 per cent as of 1987, is expected to grow to 2.3 per cent in 1994-
that is, an increase of over 50 per cent-
and to 3.2 per cent in 2000 . . .

Again, that is an increase of over 50 per cent. What are we doing? We just happen to be closing down industries right, left and centre. As they plan support and go on further and further up ahead, what are we doing? Is it not crazy that we cannot learn from the people who learnt so much from us? Where there is an Australian producer of goods that is in competition with overseas produced goods here in Australia, in any of those countries mentioned, or in third markets, suddenly our totally artificial position comes to light.
I noticed an article in the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 21 May, about the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the economy generally, which stated as follows:
Firstly, the state of the economy. Australia currently has:
* An inflation rate more than double the average of our major trading partners . . .
* The highest mortgage rates in the Western world.
* Lending rates to business up to three times as high as those in most similar economies.
* Wage growth 1.5 to two times that of similar economies.
* One of the highest gross debt interest payments to export income ratios-over 20 per cent-outside of Latin America and Eastern Europe . . .

We talk about level playing fields. None of the people that we compete with have all these obstacles to contend with. They are all obstacles that we have created. These have not been inflicted on us by anybody. These are of our own making. Every time we go further up this track, the situation gets worse.

Is it any wonder we need tariffs? Is it any wonder we need bounties, duties, quotas or whatever? We need them only because we have made no effort to get our economy in order. We have fluffed along here, year after year, getting worse and worse, eliminating industry after industry, and what have we got to show for it now? We have just got the wrecks of the empty factories around Australia. We have been kidded that all this big debt we had was going into productive equipment. That is so much hoo-ha. It is not going into productive equipment. The latest figures that have come out demonstrate this clearly. The money that has come in might have gone into personal computers, but it has not gone into manufacturing equipment that is going to turn us around this corner.

We talk about level playing fields. Do not let us talk about level playing fields. Do not even expect that it is possible for Australian producers to even survive without some form of offsetting recompense for what the non-productive sector of Australia has done to them. It is time we woke up. It is time we made the Government acknowledge that our dollar value, in particular, and our interest and inflation rates are in the mess they are, and only then let all our primary and secondary producers get out and compete without any tariffs, bounties, quotas or artificial means.

What is wrong with the wool industry at the moment? Exactly the same thing. What is wrong with some of our other manufacturing industries that are closing down? Exactly the same thing. They cannot compete because the dollar's level is ridiculous and we know that it is ridiculous. We would not be talking about various levies on the wool industry if the price of wool and the value of the dollar were okay. Why do we not face up to what the real problem is and do something about that, instead of just fiddling around the edges and looking for a scapegoat amongst those things? I do not oppose the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a refugee from the so-called reconstructed textile industry, I cannot let an opportunity such as the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill 1990 pass without comment. We are becoming more and more reliant on imported products, which is placing increasing strains on the balance of payments. I agree wholeheartedly with the yarn bounty capitalisation scheme. It is a welcome additional option for the industry, but it has to be regarded as an additional option.

In my discussions with industry a number of minor reservations have been voiced. I intend to use this forum tonight to voice those concerns. I am also seeking assurances on behalf of the industry that some of these concerns will not ultimately be realised, either intentionally or unintentionally. I welcome the appearance in the chamber of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button).

It is hoped that all applicants will be treated in an even-handed manner and that existing bounty arrangements are not prejudiced by the introduction of the scheme. I am seeking the Minister's assurances on this and a number of other matters.

I understand that it is the Government's intention that the scheme will reflect such principles but, nevertheless, I believe that assurance in this chamber from the Minister responsible is still necessary. I hope that the Government listens to the concerns that I have raised so that this Bill may be of benefit to its fullest extent to all members of the textile industry. However, some minor adjustments are necessary to the Bill, as my colleagues have ably pointed out. In summary, the Bill should prevent the possibility of double dipping and the Bill should limit the grant to expected bounty receipts in respect of existing capacity. There is one other point that I would like to make. I quote from one of Senator Button's press releases:
One of the aims of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear industry plan is to encourage TCF firms to become internationally competitive during a period of industry restructuring.

I repeat-`to become internationally competitive'. Only a few weeks ago in my home town of Launceston the Southern Garment Co. Pty Ltd announced its imminent closure. In fact, the date is very close-28 May. The reason is not the restructuring but rather, as the company manager stated, the state of the economy. The interest rates were too high on its borrowings. The banks were the only ones benefiting. So another 90 employees, another 90 families will be without part of their income as the result of the closure of another Tasmanian textile company.

The textiles, clothing and footwear industry plan has not accounted for such variables as interest rates and movements in the exchange rate, to which my colleague Senator Archer referred. The Australian dollar has dramatically appreciated since the plan was introduced. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has argued, correctly, that high interest rates will eventually reduce domestic demand and, hence, the demand for imports. However, this is only part of the story.

The impact of high interest rates has caused large changes in the relative prices of imports and their domestic substitutes. Our exchange rates are sensitive to interest rates because of the freedom of international capital flows. Thus, the Australian dollar appreciates and the competitiveness of our export industries decreases. It is not the restructuring of the industry that has caused the latest closure of the textile plant that I referred to earlier but rather, in this case, the present problem lies with the management, or lack of management, of the Australian economy. In other words, the Southern Garment Co., which employed over 90 people in Launceston, in a better economy not only may have survived, but certainly would have survived. It has gone from a thriving industry last year to an industry going out the back door, and possibly one that will have to relocate somewhere in Asia in the near future.

I draw the Senate's attention to economic literature-in particular, the Mundell-Fleming Model and the Asset Market Approach-which states that the outcome of higher interest rates actually worsens the current account. These theories support the probability that Australia is experiencing a policy induced recession to solve a current account and foreign debt problem which is, in large part, the result of the policy stance itself. I believe that this needs discussion and further review. Therefore, though I agree that the highly protected textile, clothing and footwear industry in Australia needs some restructuring, I believe that the Government should re-examine its overall economic policy to ensure that the economy is aiding Australian industry in the best interests of all concerned and is not acting to its detriment.

Finally, while I give wholehearted support to the Minister's proposal to encourage industry by all means possible to restructure so as to make itself not only locally but internationally competitive, I would like the Minister, on behalf of industry, to speak to the Treasurer of Australia to ensure that the tax legislation that he introduces supports the thrust of the proposals he is espousing in this Bill and industry at large. I seek assurances from the Minister in relation to the matters that I have raised on the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Amendment Bill. These assurances have been sought by industry. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Western Australian Health and Compensation Systems

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the instigation of people who, after unsuccessfully exploring other avenues, came to my office for help, I have over the past several months been conducting an investigation into the operation of the Western Australian health and compensation systems. It appears that the systems are failing. They tend not to serve the interests of the injured people they are intended to protect and compensate; rather they sustain a vast industry of doctors, lawyers, investigators and others who derive considerable income from the sabotage of the legitimate claims of those injured.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the system is failing in the area of prevention. It fails to inform people about the dangers and it fails to protect people from the negligence of others, such as employers. It fails also in the area of information. People are not adequately informed as to their rights, for example, with regard to safe working conditions, and about the compensation system. As a result, when people have been injured they are drawn into a system and they do not realise that they are entering a minefield in which there are very many traps and in which honesty for forthrightness can be rewarded by deceit and corruption.

Secondly, the system is failing in the area of treatment. Accounts of medical incompetence, unprofessionalism and malpractice are common, as are descriptions of how access to decent treatment is blocked by the combined workings of the existing legislation and the insurance industry. Thirdly, the system fails in the area of compensation. It legally allows people only an inadequate amount of compensation and it makes it difficult for them to obtain even that.

The ordeal of the individual begins with injury in work-related or motor vehicle accidents, or with the appearance of non-obvious conditions such as repetition strain injury (RSI) or soft tissue injuries, although people injured in other ways have recorded similar experiences with regard to the system. In one case a woman already suffering from RSI was refused an electric typewriter by her employer and when she purchased one for herself she was told that she was not allowed to bring it to work `in case it damaged the building'. Her employer, by the way, was the Western Australian Police Department.

It has been shown over and over again that industry incurs high costs as a result of poor treatment of workers and unsafe work practices. These costs, in their turn, in the form of compensation and higher insurance premiums, staff replacement, low productivity due to hours lost and low employee morale, outweigh the cost of investment in top level workplace safety. It is equally obvious that many employees do not take the matter of their own safety at work seriously enough, so there are faults on both sides.
There is also a community perception that RSI is a non-disease, either invented by malingerers or of psychological origin, and is purely an Australian phenomenon unknown in comparable countries.

Recent research shows that RSI is a very real condition and has very real physical causes, although these are not what they were once thought to be. It is also clear that there have been and continue to be epidemics of RSI in comparable countries, including Japan, the United States of America and Europe. Comparable data are not easy to compile because in different countries rather different terminology is used to name this condition.

Nevertheless, the Australian Medical Journal of September 1987 declared the RSI epidemic to be over. Worksafe Australia's new action priorities do not include RSI and the Australian Public Service no longer publishes statistics on it. The negative public, medical and institutional attitude to RSI sufferers has certainly increased their difficulties and diminished their sense of self-worth. This was surely encouraged in May 1987 when the then Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, made a spirited attack on workers who claimed to have repetitive strain injury, some of whom he labelled malingerers. It seems to me that, rather than setting out to defame citizens, governments should set out to warn them of the potential danger and assist them to stand up for their rights. Otherwise, people will continue to be unnecessarily injured.

I recognise that it is true that measures have been taken in a number of industries to guard against RSI, and I also recognise that there will always be a small minority of individuals who will attempt to exploit a compensation system to their advantage. But we do not operate our home and contents insurance policy on the assumption that every Australian who takes out a policy intends to set fire to their home with a view to making a fraudulent claim and we cannot operate our workers compensation system on the assumption that every claimant is setting out to defraud the system. It is, in fact, a reversal of the onus of proof.

RSI is a condition one contracts only as a result of working hard and fast under considerable stress for very long periods. Once injury has occurred or a condition such as RSI has manifested itself, the individual finds herself becoming involved in a huge complex system whose working she does not understand and against whose many failings she cannot protect herself. There is at present no mechanism whereby injured people are automatically fed an overview of the health and compensation system in all its medical, legal and insurance aspects, or information about their rights or lists of advisory or support organisations.

The injured person's first natural step is to consult her general practitioner (GP). If a GP decides a specialist is needed, the referral can be quite arbitrary and the patient can bounce around between the GP, physiotherapist and specialist for quite some time before striking some appropriate treatment. Some patients find themselves treated quite roughly, as if they were objects, or treated as inferiors. Commonly there is a reluctance or refusal to inform the patient what is happening, accompanied by an intimidatingly superior attitude or a demeaningly patronising one.

Patients who refuse to accept a sufficiently submissive role have reported to me that they were called malingerers or orthopaedic actresses to their faces and reduced to tears by being shouted at and told to get out of the doctor's office. One was even dismissed as a patient, regardless of the seriousness of her condition, for the sin of having openly sought a second opinion. Or again the patient may be treated as a class enemy of the medical profession. Thus, in one case a doctor privately stated that in effect one of his colleagues had been guilty of malpractice but he would never say so in public, and in another a doctor did not tell a patient the nature of her condition because it would have indicated malpractice on the part of a colleague.

Finally, many injured workers feel that they have been treated as income fodder because under the Western Australian Workers' Compensation and Assistance Act 1981 a certain amount, presently around about $16,000, is guaranteed for medical costs. Many claimants are convinced that they are over-serviced and referred unnecessarily from colleague to colleague and specialist to specialist for expensive consultations and tests until this limit is reached; then quite suddenly the medical profession loses interest in them.

Some doctors put the patient at risk without her knowledge. It appears to be common, for example, for doctors in effect to experiment on patients by trying drugs out one after the other, including new drugs or drugs banned in other countries, without informing the patient that this is what he is doing.

As I have said before, at present in Australia it is not mandatory to report adverse reactions to drugs. It is estimated that perhaps only 2 per cent of adverse reactions are in fact reported to the adverse drugs reactions advisory committee. It is also common for doctors to fail to obtain the informed consent of patients for procedures they plan to carry out, either by failing to give them virtually any information or by misinforming them about possible side effects or discomfort. One woman, for example, was told that a certain operation was so simple and minor that she would be able to drive herself home immediately; but afterwards she could not walk, let alone drive, for three days.

Another woman agreed to three little injections and was perturbed upon arriving at the hospital to find herself being prepared for theatre. The doctor would not tell her that what he had injected epidurally was Depo-medrol, about which I have had plenty to say in the past. This, of course, is a drug which the manufacturers and the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee warn should not be used epidurally. She was also not warned that, as has been described in medical journals, one of the possible side effects is the incurable condition arachnoiditis which, in fact, this patient subsequently contracted.

There seems to be perhaps something very serious missing within the education system of doctors, such as an insufficient emphasis on ethics and of patients' rights in particular. Displays of assertiveness, defiance or anger have been known to be interpreted by doctors, in reports to insurers, as signs of `psychological instability' which in turn can be and are used to deny the reality of an injury. Under section 64 of the Western Australian Workers Compensation and Assistance Act refusal to submit to treatment can result in suspension of compensation. I will read section 64 of this Act for the information of the Senate. It states:

Where a worker has given notice of a disability he shall, if so required by the employer, submit himself for examination by a medical practitioner provided and paid by the employer, and, if he, without reasonable excuse, proof of which is on him, refuses to submit himself to such an examination, or in any way obstructs it, his right to compensation, and to take or prosecute any proceeding under this Act shall be suspended until such an examination has taken place, and shall cease unless he submits himself for examination within one month after being required to do so.

People who claim compensation for permanent and total incapacity find that insurers or employers will go to extraordinary lengths to avoid even a limited liability. The legal way to deny compensation is to show either that a person's condition is not connected with the compensable situation or is not real. Once that is done the employer or insurer can, under section 1 of the Act, suspend compensation and force the claimant into a fight with the Workers Compensation Board which, generally, she will lose.

It should also be noticed in passing that the idea of defrauding the compensation system is as mythical as the myth of the unreality of RSI because, from what I have learned, no sane person would enter the system that I am describing to make money, especially as large pay-outs are remarkably uncommon. After some years of battle and extraordinary trauma the average claimant receives an award of between only $10,000 and $25,000 and, on the whole, loses money and assets.

Nevertheless, it is common for employers and insurers to place claimants under surveillance, hoping to catch them performing activities which they should not be able to perform. They do this by trying to catch them on videotapes which can then be shown to doctors or judges. These tapes are often obtained illegally. They commonly involve acts of trespass and gross invasion of people's privacy. Video film is reported to have been shot through people's bedroom windows at night using infra-red equipment. At other times surveillance is carried out quite overtly and intrusively with a view to intimidating the claimant into dropping the claim or settling out of court for a trifling amount.

One doctor has told me that such vid- eotapes are often shown to doctors, firstly, so as to discredit the claimant in the doctor's eyes before the patient has even seen him and, secondly, in order to intimidate the doctor into reserving any pro-patient opinion that he might be inclined to, lest he be laughed out of court because of the contrary evidence on the videotape. This same doctor describes one case in which the videotape shown in court was proved to be not even of the person concerned-it was somebody else who had attended that person's house to give her a hand. In another case, a claimant lost her case on the basis of a 20-second videotape which she, too, asserted to be false.
There have been a number of cases recently publicised in Perth newspapers. I will quote one from the Daily News of 22 May. A person said:

I had private investigators come to the front door and follow me to the shops. We were also harassed by debt collectors and doctors demanding payment for their services. The insurer sent me to a psychiatrist who said I was not crazy and I was ordered to have a brain scan. They also ordered a pathology test, which I later learnt was for sexually transmittable diseases. They sent me to doctors for assessment and, if there was a good report they didn't want it. They'd send me to another.
I think that gives the Senate some examples of how insurers and employers have been willing to use dirty tricks and break privacy laws to obtain information.

I would also like to quote from a statement of a man who had worked in the protective services branch of Telecom Australia. I would say that, from what he has said, that branch would seem to need some investigation. This man states that he and other Telecom employees and private investigators hired by Telecom have secretly surveilled hundreds of compensation recipients. Also, people are set up by having their car tyres let down or having rubbish thrown into their gardens to see how they would react-presumably, whether they would do actions which they say they cannot do. He states that people's pay is stopped to make them come into Telecom's office where they are covertly filmed, that eavesdropping devices are left inside claimant's homes-effectively bugging them-and that he has been directed by his superior in Telecom to use whatever methods are necessary to get the desired results, even when it was transparently obvious that the claimant was genuinely injured. All this I have in writing as a statement from this person.

He further states that many claimants have had what is known as a C-CASS run on their homes, which is a procedure whereby a print-out can be made of all numbers dialled from a telephone service in the home. He himself was instructed, when he worked for the branch, to gain access to claimants' bank accounts. He has overheard discussions on how to go about discrediting two doctors who had been sympathetic to repetitive strain injury (RSI) claimants, and he has heard claimants regularly referred to by their case managers as `slimeballs' and other names.

He concludes in this statement by saying `the mere act of lodging a compensation claim' appears to be `justification enough for claimants to be surveilled, filmed, followed, photographed, set up, vilified and have their private lives laid bare'. I can only say that such flagrantly undemocratic behaviour should not be tolerated in this country.

Very commonly, a medical basis for denying compensation is sought in any one of several forms. When applying for compensation, the injured person must sign a form giving the employer or insurer the right to see any medical reports on him. Many people do not understand that this includes reports which may predate the actual injury by years. If the records show a previous injury or natural condition, this may be seized upon to explain the current problem, or it may be claimed that a subsequent, non-compensable injury is the sole cause of the problem. One man who injured his neck at work and was awarded compensation had, four years later, to undergo minor surgery on one toe. A few days later, his neck problem flared up-as it occasionally did-and the insurer immediately suspended compensation, claiming the neck problem was a product of the toe surgery. That is really drawing a long bow.

It is sometimes claimed that claimants' problems are psychological in nature. This is particularly effective in cases of soft tissue injury and RSI, as there is still debate over their precise nature. Especially in the case of RSI, the slightest suggestion of a psychological condition can tip an already biased doctor, insurer or judge against the claimant. Details of private life, such as financial and marital problems, are commonly used to bolster such suggestions and smart claimants quickly learn to deny ever having argued with their spouses or bet on the Melbourne Cup. Should suffering, frustrated, understandably stressed claimants overstate their claims, express anger, exhibit inconsistency or behave in less than a perfectly rational way, they may find this represented in a doctor's report as a sign of instability, unreliability, and therefore dishonesty. When claimants, after long periods of pain, unemployment and frustration understandably become depressed, doctors often portray the depression as the cause rather than the effect of their problems.

To obtain one of these medical opinions as the basis for suspending compensation, employers and insurers use a process known among the claimants as `doctor shopping'. Acting under section 64 of the Act, which I previously read, this involves sending the patient to see one doctor after another until one is found who is prepared to give the necessary negative judgment. Thus, seven doctors, as has happened, may declare someone unfit for work and genuinely injured, but if the eighth disagrees compensation is immediately suspended under section 64. One woman reports being blatantly told by the State Government Insurance Commission (SGIC) that it would send her to one doctor after another until they found one who would agree to say that nothing was wrong with her. One such report is enough to suspend compensation and force the claimant to fight for reinstatement. No weight is given to expertise or familiarity with the case, and the opinions of the doctors who have previously opposed the insurers' and employers' desired assessment are simply disregarded.

There is also a variation of doctor shopping which involves the use of a pet doctor. Again and again the same few names crop up of doctors who consistently provide insurers with reports unfavourable to claimants. The reasons for such collusions are not mysterious. For those found reliable by insurance companies, there is a steady flow of business because all the higher rates are applicable in insurance cases. Again, a doctor has verified to me that `There are a number of older doctors who sustain their incomes by providing opinions for insurance companies and consequently approach the claimant with a negative attitude.'

One of these names comes up so consistently that I have been urged by many claimants and by other doctors to name him in the Senate. Since there is now the right of reply, I shall do so. A large proportion of the many RSI sufferers who have been in contact with my office-and they number now about 80-have mentioned Dr P. Ingram Cromack as being the doctor responsible for ceasing their compensation payments or putting them in jeopardy. But again, in the final analysis, the practice of doctor shopping is underpinned by sections 64 and 65 of the State Act which not only do not serve the community's best interests, but occasionally even place people at the mercy of criminals. A doctor sexually assaulted one claimant, then threatened to report her as needing psychiatric help if she charged him. She did not charge him.

Once compensation has been denied the claimant's only recourse is to legal action. But although the law is supposedly the very backbone of our democratic society, access to it is reserved, certainly in Western Australia, for the most part-to put it bluntly-for the wealthy. A claimant who seeks to use the courts to obtain justice commonly experiences a similar range of problems as she has by this time experienced with the medical profession. It must be clear by now that sections at least of the legislation can work against the rights and interests of the genuine claimant.

Until December 1986 it was possible to make a total liability claim against the employer for the full amount one would have earned over the rest of one's working life, but at that time the Act was amended in unusual haste. The amendments completed their passage through the State Parliament just nine days after they were introduced and without being normally gazetted as to limit total liability awards to just $50,000. A large number of asbestosis claims suddenly began to surface at that very same time. In Ben Hill's book, Blue Murder, which is the story of the blue asbestos mine at Wittenoom in Western Australia, Robert Vojakaovic, President of the Asbestos Diseases Society (Inc) of Australia reports how some time earlier he had sought an interview with the then Australian Premier, Brian Burke, in which he planned to ask him to look again for crucial State Government records of the Wittenoom mine. I quote briefly from this book:

`As soon as I walked into his office, he jumped to his feet and shouted at me ``you are trying to bankrupt this State, and I won't let you''. What he was talking about was the compensation we were fighting for-the State Government Insurance Office was the liability insurer at Wittenoom, and Burke was terrified they would end up picking up the bill for millions and millions of dollars. I calmed him down, and proposed a deal to him: either a Royal Commission, at which everything would have to come out, or find those missing documents so that we could use them in our court cases against CSR. He saw the sense of that, and told the public servants to go and have another look.' . . . eventually, piece by piece, page by page, week by week, from filing cabinets and warehouses all over the city, and in Kalgoorlie and Karratha, the bureaucracy yielded up its secrets-and it suddenly became clear why they had fought so hard to prevent them becoming public. The Wittenoom Papers reveal a story of bureaucratic incompetence and inertia almost unrivalled in Australian political history . . .

I could continue. Regardless of precisely why the legislation was amended in 1986, it was made full use of in a variety of cases. One person made a large total liability claim against her employer, the Western Australian Education Department-that is, the State-and it was due to go to trial just before the date the amendments were passed. The Western Australian Crown Law Department's lawyers acting on behalf of the State delayed the trial, by such tactics as quite simply failing to turn up, to attend meetings, until the amendments had been passed.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, the workers' compensation and motor vehicle insurance schemes were established to protect the hurt and the injured. Those systems, at least as they operate in Western Australia, have been diverted from their true purpose. They often act like a cancer which preys upon people. The systems that were set up to protect and compensate people do not sufficiently do that. At the same time, a whole army of doctors, paramedics, lawyers, insurers and even government-if government can make a profit on workers' compensation via its agency, the State Government Insurance Commission-seem to benefit rather than those who should.
